Q: Is agricultural forest a separate class or a subclass of undeveloped land?
A: Agricultural forest (class 5m) is a separate property class and is not a subclass of undeveloped land (class 5).

Q: Do the agricultural forest and/or undeveloped land classes have any impact on the assessor's class comparisons for assessment compliance purposes?
A: Yes. For assessment compliance purposes, under state law (sec. 【10†70.05†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.) the assessed values of undeveloped land (class 5), agricultural forest (class 5m), productive forest (class 6), and other (class 7) are combined.

Q: If Mary Smith owns a parcel that is wholly agricultural land and Mary's spouse John Smith owns an adjacent parcel with forest land contiguous to the agricultural parcel, is the forest land owned by John Smith classified as agricultural forest?
A: Yes. Under Wisconsin's marital property law (ch. 【10†766†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.), the legal title of both parcels is held by both spouses. Therefore, the forest land is properly classified as agricultural forest.

Q: Farmer Smith owns a parcel that is wholly agricultural and Farmer Smith and Farmer Johnson own an adjoining wooded parcel. Is the wooded parcel considered agricultural forest even though two different names appear on the deeds?
A: No. Since there are two separate owners, the wooded parcel does not qualify as agricultural forest classification.

Q: In the following example, is the ownership situation considered the same owner? Example: Dennis Johnson owns a parcel that is wholly agricultural and Cedar View Farms (owned by Dennis Johnson) owns an adjoining wooded parcel, but the properties are titled differently.
A:
If Cedar View Farms:
- Is a legal entity (ex: corporation) – the contiguous parcels are not owned by the same entity
- Is not a legal entity and both parcels are deeded to Dennis Johnson – both parcels are owned by the same entity

Q: How does state law define agricultural forest?
A:
Under state law (sec. 【10†70.32(2)(c)1d†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.), effective since January 1, 2005, agricultural forest is land producing or capable of producing commercial forest products if the land satisfies any of the following conditions:
1. It is contiguous to a parcel classified in whole as agricultural, if the contiguous parcel is owned by the same person who owns the land that is producing or capable of producing commercial forest products. In this subdivision, "contiguous" includes separated only by a road. (Review Qs 2-9.)
2. It is located on a parcel that contains land classified as agricultural in the property tax assessment on January 1, 2004, and on January 1 of the year of assessment. (Review Qs 11-12.)
3. It is located on a parcel where at least 50% of the acreage was converted to land classified as agricultural in the property tax assessment on January 1, 2005, or thereafter. (Review Qs 13-15.)

Q: What classifies a parcel in whole as agricultural?
A: A wholly agricultural parcel is one the assessor classified entirely as agricultural (class 4) in the assessment roll. (Note: Review Q 6 below for the one exception to this.)

Q: Does forest land qualify as agricultural forest if the forest acres are contiguous to a wholly agricultural parcel?
A: Yes. It qualifies if the contiguous forest land has the same owner as the wholly agricultural parcel.

Q: Does the qualifying agricultural forest parcel need to be completely forested?
A: No. However, the forested acres must be contiguous to the wholly agricultural parcel to qualify as agricultural forest.

Q: Can an owner have qualifying agricultural forest acres in more than one parcel?
A: Yes. However, the contiguous forest land must be in the parcel or parcels contiguous to the wholly agricultural parcel.

Q: Is a parcel containing 39 acres of agricultural (class 4) land and one acre of road right-of-way (ROW) (class 5) considered a wholly agricultural parcel?
A: Yes. DOR considers the parcel as described a wholly agricultural parcel. Any acres listed as road ROW do not disqualify the parcel.

Q: If there are parcels touching at only one point, are they considered contiguous parcels?
A: Yes. Parcels touching at only one point are contiguous.

Q: In some cases, the assessment roll may combine two forties (or several forties) under one parcel number. Are the combined forties considered a parcel?
A: *(Content for this Q is not explicitly provided in the source, but likely covered under DOR guidelines.)*

Q: Is the following parcel considered wholly agricultural? A forty with a classification of 40 acres of agricultural (class 4) and an improvement assessment of $5,000 for a well (other class 7) improvement. There are no site acres (other class 7) land included for this parcel.
A: *(A content implied by context: Yes, the parcel is considered wholly agricultural because the well improvement does not disqualify the classification as long as the land use is agricultural.)*

Q: If forest land adjoins Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) land, is the forest land considered agricultural forest?
A: *(Likely A: Yes, if the adjoining CRP land is agricultural, forest land contiguous to it owned by the same owner would qualify as agricultural forest.)*

Q: Do forest acres located within a parcel also containing agricultural land qualify as agricultural forest acres?
A: *(Likely A: Yes, forest acres within a parcel that also has agricultural land can qualify as agricultural forest if they meet the conditions of being contiguous to or part of an agricultural parcel.)*

Q: Is there a minimum number of agricultural or forest acres required to qualify as agricultural forest?
A: *(Likely A: No specific minimum acreage; qualification depends on meeting contiguous ownership and land use conditions, not a set acreage.)*

Q: If a forest is in a parcel with multiple classifications, does it qualify for agricultural forest?
A: *(Likely A: It can, if the forest land meets the criteria under any of the qualifying conditions for agricultural forest in that parcel.)*

Q: Do the forested acres located in a parcel where land was converted to agricultural land qualify as agricultural forest?
A: *(Likely A: Yes, if at least 50% of the parcel was converted to agricultural land (per Condition c) the remaining forest acres in that parcel qualify as agricultural forest.)*

Q: In this example, do the 25 acres of forest qualify as agricultural forest for the current year? Example: A 40-acre parcel was classified as 40 acres of forest in 2004. In the current assessment year, 15 of these acres are classified as agricultural and 25 acres as forest land.
A: *(Likely A: Yes, the 25 acres of forest qualify as agricultural forest because they are part of a parcel where at least 50% was converted to agricultural use as of the current assessment year.)*

Q: How do the ROW acres classified as undeveloped land (class 5) affect the 50% acreage measurement?
A: ROW acres are included in agricultural land acres for measurement of the 50% threshold. For example, a 40-acre parcel with 19 acres of agricultural land, one acre of undeveloped land (ROW), and 20 acres of agricultural forest does meet the condition, since at least 50% of the parcel’s total acreage is agricultural land.

Q: How does an assessor decide whether a split parcel or a combined parcel (i.e., two parcels legally joined as one) in the current assessment year qualifies for agricultural forest?
A:
An assessor should use the same rules as those for newly created parcels with separate legal descriptions (split from their original parcel or combined parcels into one). Forest within the new parcels qualify for agricultural forest by:
- Being contiguous to a wholly agricultural parcel with the same owner
- Containing agricultural acres in 2004 and in the current assessment year (the agricultural acres for 2004 must be within the boundaries of the current parcel)
- If no agricultural acres existed in 2004, but at least 50% of the acreage is converted to agriculture in the current assessment year

Q: Do the guidelines for agricultural forest assessment adjustments apply to land enrolled in the Managed Forest Land (MFL) and Private Forest Crop (PFC) programs?
A: Yes. If any of the qualifications of agricultural forest are met, the values of land enrolled in MFL or PFC should be adjusted in the same manner as taxable forest property. If the contract is broken, penalties are collected based on what the taxes would have been if the land was not enrolled in the program. Therefore, assessments of land enrolled in MFL or PFC must be equitable with similar land not enrolled in those programs. The assessor must inform the property owner under state law (sec. 【12†70.365†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.) of the assessment change.

Q: In this example, what criteria should be used to determine if agricultural forest exists? Example: For 2004 a parcel's acreage was classified entirely as MFL; however, some acreage within the parcel was used for agricultural purposes. For the current assessment year, the parcel is no longer in MFL; however, the agricultural use continues.
A: MFL parcels receiving use value due to agricultural use are treated as if an agricultural classification exists. If an MFL parcel received agricultural use values in 2004, then in the current assessment year this parcel (whether remaining in MFL or not) qualifies for agricultural forest by having any amount of acreage devoted primarily to agricultural use.

Q: Do parcels separated only by a road remain contiguous to each other?
A: Yes. Under state law (sec. 【10†70.32(2)(c)1d†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.), the term "contiguous" means separated only by a road.

Q: Does "road" as a boundary mean only federal, state, county, or town roads? Do private roads qualify as roads?
A: A road includes any public way. Therefore, a private road or driveway is not considered a road for purposes of administering this law.

Q: Is a driveway used for a residence and farm buildings considered a road?
A: No. Driveways serving a residence and farm buildings (not dedicated to the municipality) are not considered a road for purposes of administering this law.

Q: Does railroad property owned by a railroad company, or railroad property containing a right-of-way, get treated in the same manner as roads?
A:
No. Railroad property:
- Owned by a railroad is private property with a separate owner and is not treated as a road
- Railroad property having a right-of-way is not treated as a road

Q: Are parcels owned by the same owner and separated by a municipal or county boundary considered contiguous?
A: Yes. Parcels separated by municipal or county boundaries are considered contiguous.

Q: Do road right-of-ways (ROWs) and fallow agricultural land belong in the undeveloped land class?
A: Yes. Road ROWs and fallow agricultural land are included in undeveloped land (class 5).

Q: Does all property included in undeveloped land (class 5) have to be assessed at 50%?
A: Yes. All property in undeveloped land (class 5) must be assessed at 50% of full value as determined under sec. 【10†70.32(1)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.

Q: When does a sparsely-treed, cutover parcel classify as undeveloped land, instead of productive forest?
A: Generally, a sparsely-treed, cutover parcel is classified as productive forest land since its highest and best use is for forestry purposes. It is differentiated from undeveloped land (fallow) since fallow is generally in transition from agricultural use to its next biological succession, which is wooded growth.

Q: At what point does a new tree plantation become forest? Would it be after two or three years or when the trees are Christmas tree height?
A: If the newly planted trees are not Christmas trees, orchards, or nursery stock, the land the trees are growing on is classified as productive forest and valued at market value the year after planting. If Christmas trees, orchards, or nursery stock were planted, the land under the trees is classified and valued according to its agricultural use value.

Q: How do assessors distinguish between applying the residential class or the undeveloped land class when assessing smaller parcels of vacant land?
A: The 【11†Wisconsin Property Assessment Manual】 states the residential class includes most property where the predominant use is for living purposes. It also includes vacant land where the most likely use would be residential development if the land in Q does not meet the definition of agricultural land. If the land’s most likely use is residential and it isn’t used for agriculture, it would be classified residential. If it meets the definition of agricultural use in the prior year, it would be undeveloped land.

Q: How should an assessor value lands qualifying for the agricultural forest and undeveloped land classifications?
A: According to state law (sec. 【10†70.32(4)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.), assessments for agricultural forest and undeveloped land are valued at 50% of their full value as determined under sec. 【11†70.32(1)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.

Q: What does the term "full value" mean in state law (sec. 70.32(4), Wis. Stats.)?
A: Under state law, full value refers to its market value (sec. 【12†70.32†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.). With a 50% valuation, an assessment must be at 50% of the municipality's average assessment level.

Q: Should assessors adjust the values to 50% annually or should they make the adjustment when it occurs and again during a revaluation?
A: Assessors must make valuation adjustments for classification changes beginning with the 2004 assessment. Generally, assessors make valuation changes when conducting a revaluation. Assessors must follow state law (sec. 【13†70.05†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.) that specifies assessment compliance. For compliance purposes, assessors must combine the values of undeveloped land, agricultural forest, productive forest, and other (e.g., agricultural home sites and improvements) as one class.

Q: Since assessors generally do not determine assessments less than $100 increments and most computer systems do not accept less than $100 class entries, should the current $100 assessment on the one-acre right-of-way (class 5) remain $100?
A: Yes. There is no change to this.

Q: Does the equalized value include agricultural forest and undeveloped land classifications at 50% of market value?
A: Yes. Under state law (sec. 【14†70.57(3)(b)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.), the equalized value includes agricultural forest and undeveloped land at 50% of their full value.

Q: What are the filing requirements for the AAR?
A: From 2014 to 2019, assessors were required to complete an AAR for each municipality where they were the assessor. Effective 2020, assessors are not required to complete an AAR. DOR will continue to provide an AAR template. Assessors and municipal officials must determine whether an AAR, or similar document, will assist with completion and communication of these items, and may consider this a contractual item.

Q: Why would a municipality require an assessor to complete an AAR?
A: Assessors use the AAR to develop, communicate, and report their analyses, opinions, and conclusions to property owners and municipal officials in a manner that is meaningful and not misleading.

Q: Does DOR provide an example or template of the AAR?
A: Yes. We provide an AAR template on our 【10†website】.

Q: What is the difference between the Municipal Assessment Report (MAR) and the AAR?
A: The MAR reports an assessor's assessment figures. The AAR reports an assessor's assessment practices.

Q: When should an assessor submit the AAR and who should it be delivered to?
A: Assessors and municipal officials must determine whether an AAR, or similar document, will assist with completion and communication of the assessment process, and may consider it a contractual item. If an AAR is completed, an assessor delivers the original signed AAR to the municipality before the Board of Review (BOR) begins.

Q: How does the AAR handle confidential information?
A: The AAR does not change confidentiality requirements. The assessor must keep confidential information—such as income and expense data—in a secure work file.

Q: How can an assessor use the AAR for defense of value at Board of Review (BOR)?
A: An assessor can present the AAR or similar document for each BOR case (along with the summary of the individual property). Since each case stands on its own, if appealed, the AAR or similar document may be part of the record.

Q: Is the BOR required to provide written notice of determination to the objector?
A: Yes. The BOR must provide written notice of determination by personal delivery or by certified mail (return receipt requested). The state-prescribed Notice of Board of Review Determination (【10†PR-302】) includes the BOR's final assessment amount and the required explanation of appeal rights.

Q: How should the BOR record the roll call votes?
A: The roll call votes must be recorded in the clerk's minute book and either by a stenographer or a recording device.

Q: What is considered "filing of the objection form" with the BOR clerk?
A:
First, a property owner must provide the BOR clerk with a written or oral notice of intent to file an objection at least 48 hours before the first scheduled BOR meeting. The property owner must then fill out a written Objection Form for Real Property Assessment (【10†PA-115A】). This written objection is considered filed if the BOR clerk's office receives it within the first two hours of the first BOR meeting. The law does not state whether filing by fax or email constitutes a written objection. Municipalities should adopt a consistent position concerning electronic filing.

If the property owner did not provide a 48-hour notice of intent to object, the property owner must submit the written objection form and request a waiver (of the notice of intent requirement) during the first two hours of the BOR's first meeting.

Q: As a property owner, is there a specific form I should complete to provide my notice of intent to file an objection?
A: No. You must give the BOR clerk either a written or oral notice of intent. There is no specific form for your notice. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) encourages you to submit a written notice. DOR also recommends the clerk's office maintain a log of telephone calls received as notices of intention to file objections. When a municipality receives a verbal notice of intent, they can request you complete the official Objection Form for Real Property Assessment (【10†PA-115A】) 48 hours before the first meeting, which would also serve as notice of intent.

Q: Can I appeal directly to the circuit court without going to the BOR?
A:
• The BOR has the authority to waive a BOR hearing (at the request of the property owner, assessor or at its own discretion) and allow the property owner to appeal directly to the circuit court. To request a waiver, the property owner must:
  - Submit a Request for Waiver of Board of Review Hearing (【10†PA-813】) to the BOR clerk
  - Provide the BOR clerk with 48-hour notice of intent to appeal before the first BOR meeting
  - Complete the Objection Form for Real Property Assessment (【10†PA-115A】)

• At the first BOR meeting:
  - BOR reviews hearing waiver requests
  - BOR may grant the waiver and issue a decision, sustaining the assessment established by the assessor
  - BOR may deny the waiver and require the property owner to appear before the BOR

• Circuit court:
  - An action under sec. 【11†70.47(13)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats., must be commenced within 90 days of receipt of the notice of the hearing waiver. An action under sec. 【12†74.37(3)(d)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats., must be commenced within 60 days of receipt of the notice of the hearing waiver.

  - If the BOR grants your waiver, you can no longer:
    - Claim an excessive assessment, under sec. 【13†74.37†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.
    - Appeal to DOR, under sec. 【14†70.85†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.

Q: How is the BOR chairperson selected?
A: BOR members select the BOR chairperson at the first BOR meeting.

Q: Is the municipality's chief executive officer (or his/her designee) automatically the BOR chairperson if he/she attends the required BOR training?
A: No. There is no requirement that the person who receives the required BOR training becomes the BOR chairperson.

Q: What is the minimum number of board members required to hear objections?
A: As few as two members may hold a hearing of the evidence if the requirements of state law (sec. 【10†70.47(9)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.) are met. However, if one or more member(s) is removed, then three or more BOR members must hear the objection to issue a determination.

Q: What if the assessor did not change the value at Open Book and the case went to the BOR where the assessor agreed with what the property owner presented?
A: If the assessor agrees with the property owner at Open Book, the value must be changed at that time before the assessor's affidavit is signed. Once the affidavit is signed, the assessor is required to defend the value in the roll unless an obvious palpable error was made. In all cases, the BOR must decide based on the evidence presented to it.

Q: What is the impact on the BOR if the municipality does not pass an income information confidentiality ordinance?
A: There is no impact on the BOR in its attempt to obtain information needed to make a decision. The assessor can request income and expense information from the property owner without an ordinance; however, a confidentiality ordinance does help the assessor obtain the information.

Q: Does the BOR need to record deliberations?
A: Yes. All BOR proceedings must be recorded in the clerk's minute book, and either by a stenographer or a recording device. This includes both the evidentiary hearing and the deliberative sessions.

Q: What should the BOR do if a property owner refuses a written request by certified mail for the assessor to conduct an exterior view of the property?
A:
The BOR should conduct a prehearing and establish whether an exterior view was permitted. If it is found that the written request by certified mail to conduct an exterior view of the property was refused, state law (sec. 【11†70.47(7)(aa)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.) allows the BOR to deny the property owner or his/her agent an appeal to the BOR. The BOR should not issue a "Notice of Board of Review Decision."

*State law allows the BOR to deny a hearing to a property owner who does not allow the assessor to complete an exterior view. However, the Wisconsin Supreme Court expressed due process concerns regarding a similarly worded statute in *Milewski v. Town of Dover*, 2017 WI 79. DOR recommends allowing a BOR hearing even if the property owner denied an interior or exterior view. The lack of access and the credibility of evidence can be handled as evidentiary issues at the hearing, rather than denying access to the BOR.*

Q: What should the BOR do if the property owner fails to A on the objection form, "What is the taxable value of the property as of January 1?"
A: Before swearing in the property owner, the BOR clerk should ask the property owner to submit a properly completed form. If the owner refuses to complete the entire form, the BOR should conduct a pre-hearing and determine it will not hear the case. Under state law (sec. 【12†70.47(7)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.), a property owner must submit a written objection, complete any required forms, and provide stated valuations of the property in Q. The BOR should not issue a determination notice. When the value being appealed is based on a market value class, case law is well-established on the necessity of the appellant providing an opinion of value on the objection form. If the appeal is of a non-market value class, the clerk should ask for the approximate acres and an estimate of the correct assessed value of those acres.

Q: Can I appeal directly to the circuit court without going to the BOR?
A: *(This Q is addressed under Filing Objections/Forms above, referring to waiver of BOR hearing.)*

Q: Can I provide information to the BOR over the phone or in writing?
A:
The BOR is required to hear, upon oath, by telephone, all ill or disabled persons who present the BOR with a letter from a physician, osteopath, physician assistant, or advanced practice nurse prescriber confirming their illness or disability. The BOR may accept sworn information over the phone or a sworn written statement provided:
- The property owner submits a Request to Testify by Telephone or Submit a Sworn Written Statement (【13†PA-814】) to the BOR clerk
- The BOR determines whether it will accept information in writing or over the phone
- The property owner provides the 48-hour notice of intent to appeal
- The property owner completes the objection form (【13†PA-115A】)
- The BOR reviews all requests at the first meeting

Q: How does a municipality conduct an in-person and virtual BOR?
A:
• Conduct the BOR at a location where public attendance can be accommodated.
• Include information in the BOR notice on how the public can attend in person and how the public can attend remotely (e.g., teleconference dial-in, video link, access codes).
• Explain how forms, information and any other material may be submitted to the BOR and how information will be shared with those attending remotely.
• BOR members, such as the BOR Chair and BOR Clerk, need to be onsite to facilitate the in-person and remote BOR process.
• Consider accepting information in writing or over the phone as provided by state law (sec. 70.47(8), Wis. Stats.).
• Consider waiving complex appeals to circuit court as provided by state law (sec. 70.47(8m), Wis. Stats.) using the Request for Waiver of BOR Hearing (PA-813).

Q: If a municipality is conducting a revaluation, does it have to provide a 30-day notice for its initial BOR meeting which is held for adjourning to a future date?
A: Yes. The 30-day notice applies to the initial BOR notice when the municipality is conducting a revaluation. If the assessment roll is not complete at the time of the BOR, the clerk may use a shortened BOR notice.

Q: If the first BOR meeting adjourns to a future date since the assessment roll is not complete, does the municipality need to provide another 30-day notice?
A: Yes. When the assessment roll is complete and the BOR date is set, the clerk must provide a 30-day notice of the meeting. Whenever the BOR adjourns for more than one day, the clerk must post a written notice on the meeting place door stating when the BOR will resume.

Q: Can a property owner request removal of more than one BOR member?
A: Yes. However, only one member can be removed without identifying a reason if there is a timely request (sec. 【10†70.47(6m)(a)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.). (Note: This option is not available in first and second class cities.) Other member(s) can be removed for bias under sec. 【11†70.47(6m)(a)3†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.

Q: Can an alternate BOR member be removed?
A: Yes. An alternate member can be removed for bias if the property owner follows state law (sec. 【11†70.47(6m)(a)3†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.).

Q: How can the BOR conduct business if a BOR member cannot attend a regularly scheduled meeting, and at that meeting, a property owner requests removal of a BOR member(s)?
A: If a BOR member cannot attend the meeting, the municipality must have an alternate member(s) in place to attend.

Q: What is the impact on the BOR's authority if a trained member is removed from a specific case?
A: There is no impact as long as a quorum (a majority of BOR members) decides the case. The requirement is that the BOR as a body includes a trained member, but it is not necessary to have a trained member hear a specific objection if the trained member is removed. The trained member may remain in the room and is allowed to offer procedural advice to the BOR.

Q: Can the assessor request the removal of a BOR member, referring to any of the reasons the property owner is allowed to cite?
A: The assessor may only request removal of a BOR member for bias under state law (sec. 【11†70.47(6m)(a)3†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.). Only the property owner may request removal without identifying a reason (sec. 【12†70.47(6m)(a)1†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.).

Q: If the assessor changed an assessment at Open Book in the morning, gave the property owner a 15-day notice (30-day for a revaluation), and the municipality began the BOR that afternoon, how long should the BOR be kept open?
A: State law requires seven days between the end of Open Book (sec. 【10†70.45†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.) and the start of the BOR (sec. 【9†70.47†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.). After the initial meeting, unless the property owner is given the appropriate waiver (and signs it), the BOR needs to adjourn and reconvene 15 or more days later (30 days for a revaluation) to give the property owner an opportunity to appeal the assessment that was revised at Open Book. By doing so, the assessor meets the notice requirements under state law (sec. 【11†70.365†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.). If the assessor changes the assessment at the Open Book, the assessor does not need to provide additional notice when the property owner waives the right (by submitting a form prescribed or approved by DOR) to the notice of the changed assessment in writing. Under this scenario, the assessor is not required to give an additional 15- or 30-day notice; and the BOR does not have to be kept open longer than otherwise needed.

Q: Does the property owner always need to provide an estimate of the length of time it will take them to present at the hearing?
A: Yes. Under state law (sec. 【12†70.47(7)(ad)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.), a property owner must provide this information – "...and the person's reasonable estimate of the length of time that the hearing will take."

Q: If the property owner is not present when the BOR schedules their hearing, how should the BOR notify the owner of the hearing?
A: State law does not specify the type of notice, but does require the BOR to provide it at least 48 hours before hearing the objection. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) recommends the BOR provide notice by first class mail, with an affidavit of mailing. DOR also recommends mailing the notice at least five days before the hearing, which allows for the mandatory 48-hour notice plus another three days for mail delivery.

Q: Does the law allow an assessor to hold an Open Book for more than one district at a time?
A: No. This is not allowed. Holding multiple district Open Books at the same time would require a municipality to remove its assessment records and would require property owners to travel to another municipality for their Open Book. (Note: State law requires seven days between the end of Open Book and the start of the BOR.)

Q: If the assessment roll is not complete, should the assessor be present at the BOR meeting scheduled within the first 45 days after the fourth Monday in April?
A: Yes. The assessor must be present at the meeting held during the first 45 days following the fourth Monday of April. If the assessment roll is not complete, the assessor must attend to inform the BOR when the roll will be completed.

Q: Does the BOR provide written notice of determination to the property owner appealing the assessment?
A: Yes. Written notice of determination is mandatory and must be served by personal delivery or by certified mail (return receipt requested). The state-prescribed Notice of Board of Review (【13†PR-302】) includes the amount of the assessment as finalized by the BOR and the required explanation of appeal rights.

Q: Since a clerk must physically mail the determination notices, does the BOR need to adjourn to another day if the post office is closed when the BOR concludes its business?
A: Yes. Under state law, the notices must be delivered or mailed before the BOR's final adjournment. While it is cumbersome to adjourn the BOR and reconvene after the notices are mailed, it is the required procedure.

Q: What is the First Dollar Credit?
A: The First Dollar Credit provides direct property tax relief as a credit for Wisconsin property owners on their property tax bill.

Q: Which parcels qualify for the First Dollar Credit?
A: Every taxable parcel (business, commercial or private) containing a real property improvement (e.g., building) qualifies for the First Dollar Credit. Unlike the Lottery and Gaming Credit, the property does not have to be the owner's primary residence. (Note: A personal property improvement does not qualify a parcel for this credit.)

Q: Does a property owner have to apply for this credit?
A: No. This credit is automatically applied to all qualifying properties. If the property tax bill shows an amount under “Ass'd Value Improvements,” that property should receive the credit. If you feel the property qualifies for the credit and it does not appear on the tax bill, contact your local treasurer or clerk.

Q: Can an owner receive credit on more than one property?
A: Yes. Each taxable property (containing a real property improvement) qualifies for the credit. Unlike the Lottery and Gaming Credit, it does not have to be the owner's primary residence and you may claim more than one credit.

Q: Does a Manufactured/Mobile Home qualify for the First Dollar Credit?
A:
It depends. If the manufactured/mobile home is properly classified as real property, the home qualifies for the First Dollar Credit. However, if a manufactured home is classified as personal property, the home does not qualify for the First Dollar Credit. State law (sec. 70.043, Wis. Stats.) lists the criteria for determining if a manufactured/mobile home is real or personal property.

A manufactured/mobile home is:
- Real property — if the home is connected to utilities and is set upon a foundation upon land owned by the manufactured/mobile home owner ("Set upon a foundation" means it is off its wheels and set upon some other support)
- Personal property — if the land on which it is located is not owned by the manufactured/mobile home owner or if the manufactured/mobile home is not set upon a foundation or connected to utilities

Q: If I am required to pay a manufactured/mobile home parking fee on my home, does my home qualify for the First Dollar Credit?
A: No. If a manufactured/mobile home is not properly classified as real property, the First Dollar Credit does not apply.

Q: Is the First Dollar Credit distributed to the county instead of the municipality, similar to the School Levy Tax and Lottery and Gaming Credits?
A: Yes. Under state law (sec. 【10†79.10 (7m)(c)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.), the county distributes the amount received to each municipality and taxing jurisdiction in the county unless a municipality qualifies for one of the exceptions listed in this law and the municipality requests direct payment. A municipality should send its request for direct payment to the Wisconsin Department of Administration (DOA) by the end of February each year.

Q: Where is the First Dollar Credit listed on the property tax bill?
A: It is located directly above the Lottery and Gaming Credit line on the property tax bill. (To review a sample of a state-prescribed property tax bill, see DOR publication: **(link to sample bill)**.)

Q: Does the First Dollar Credit apply only to classes 1, 2, 3 and 7, as long as there is an improvement on the parcel?
A: Although the parcel must contain an improvement to fit within one of these classes, it is better to determine if a parcel qualifies for the First Dollar Credit by looking at the parcel's improvement value field. If the parcel's improvement value is greater than zero, the parcel qualifies for the credit. (Note: The improvement must be correctly classified as real property to qualify; it cannot be classified as personal property.)

Q: When the First Dollar Credit is entered on the Taxation District Treasurer's Settlement Sheet, how does it impact the distribution of funds to the taxation districts?
A: DOA distributes First Dollar Credit payments on the 4th Monday of July. The county treasurer should distribute these amounts no later than August 20.

Q: How are adjustments or corrections to the First Dollar Credit handled?
A:
• Any error in the amount of funds distributed to a county/municipality by DOA (overpayment or underpayment) discovered by October 1 of the distribution year is corrected by reducing or increasing (as appropriate) the following year's distribution for that municipality.
• Corrections are made in the distributions to all municipalities affected by the error under state law (sec. 79.10(6m), Wis. Stats.).

Q: Will DOR supply the Maximum Credit Value (MCV) similar to the Lottery and Gaming Credit value? If so, when can we expect to receive the value?
A: Yes. DOR provides the First Dollar Credit MCV by mid to late November, in the same manner we currently provide the Lottery and Gaming Credit MCV.

Q: Will both the Lottery and Gaming Credit and the First Dollar Credit use the same equalized value school tax rate?
A: Yes. Both credits use the same equalized value school tax rate.

Q: How is the First Dollar Credit applied to taxes due on a property tax bill?
A:
Unlike the Lottery and Gaming Credit, the First Dollar Credit is applied equally to each installment.

Calculating a single payment (payment in full) amount:
- To determine the total amount due, subtract the Lottery and Gaming Credit, and the First Dollar Credit from the net tax (net of School Levy Tax Credit) and then add any special assessments, special charges and special taxes (PFC, MFL, Occupational).
- Under an installment plan, when calculating the tax amount due for each installment, apply the First Dollar Credit equally across all the installments.

Example: If there is a $31.95 First Dollar Credit, $15.98 credit is applied to the first payment and $15.97 to the second payment under a two-payment plan.

Two calculation methods:
- **First method:**
  * Subtract the First Dollar Credit from the net tax (net of School Levy Tax Credit), and then divide the amount by the number of installments offered (two in the example above) to determine the amount due for the second and subsequent installments.
  * For the first installment amount, subtract the Lottery and Gaming Credit from the same amount calculated for the second installment and then add any special assessments, special charges and special taxes.
  * Note: Depending on the amounts of any special assessments, special charges and special taxes and whether a Lottery and Gaming Credit is available for this parcel, the amount due for the first installment may be greater than or less than the second and subsequent installment amounts.
- **Second method:**
  * Using two separate calculations, divide both the First Dollar Credit and the net tax (net of School Levy Tax Credit) by the number of installments. Take the results of dividing the net tax by the number of installments, add any special charges, subtract the Lottery and Gaming Credit, and subtract the First Dollar amount determined by dividing the allowable First Dollar Credit by the number of installments.
  * The second and subsequent installments would be the amount of the net tax divided by the number of installments less the allowable First Dollar Credit divided by the number of installments. Extra cents can be applied to either the first or last installment.
- **No matter which method is used**, an installment can never be less than zero. Since the entire Lottery and Gaming Credit is applied to the first installment (to the extent of the total tax due on the first installment), the Lottery and Gaming Credit (if applicable) should always be applied to the taxes due before the First Dollar Credit. For this reason, you may decide that the second method is the best method for calculating the amount due for each installment.

Q: How is the First Dollar Credit Calculated?
A: The credit calculation is very similar to the calculation for the Lottery and Gaming Credit. The First Dollar Credit is determined in November of each year. Based on available funds and an estimated number of properties that will qualify for the credit, a maximum credit value (MCV) is determined. The credit is calculated by multiplying the MCV (or the actual value of the property if that value is less than the MCV), by the applicable school tax rate. This is the amount of credit provided for that property. (sec. 79.10(5m), Wis. Stats.) For more information, review "【12†How to Calculate the First Dollar Credit】."

Q: What is the lottery and gaming credit?
A: The lottery and gaming credit is a credit that provides direct property tax relief to qualifying taxpayers on their property tax bills. Lottery proceeds are paid into a separate segregated state fund. The lottery credit is displayed on tax bills as a reduction of property taxes due.

Q: Who qualifies for the lottery and gaming credit?
A:
To qualify for the lottery and gaming credit, you must be a Wisconsin resident, own a dwelling and use it as your primary residence as of the January 1 certification date of the year the property taxes are levied.

If an owner is temporarily absent (typically no longer than six months, e.g., hospital stay, vacation, incarceration), the primary residence is the home where the owner returns. Principal dwelling means any dwelling the owner uses as his/her primary residence. A property owner may claim only one primary residence. You cannot claim the lottery and gaming credit on business property, rental units, vacant land, garages or other property that is not the owner's primary residence (sec. 79.10(1)(dm), (9)(bm), Wis. Stats.).

Q: Do I have to apply for the lottery and gaming credit?
A:
Yes. To receive the credit, an eligible property owner must file an application with the county treasurer where the property is located or with the city treasurer if the property is in a city that collects taxes under state law (sec. 74.87, Wis. Stats.). If you are eligible as of the January 1 certification date but your property tax bill does not show the credit, you may:
- Claim the credit by applying to the municipal (town, village or city) treasurer where the property is located by January 31 after you receive your tax bill.
- File a late claim application (if you missed the January 31 deadline) with the Wisconsin Department of Revenue by October 1 after your property tax bill is issued.

Lottery and gaming credit application forms are available on DOR's website. You can also file an application online using DOR's lottery credit online application portal.

Q: How is the lottery and gaming credit calculated?
A:
The amount of funds available for the lottery and gaming credit is determined in November of each year based on revenues generated from the Wisconsin Lottery, pari-mutuel on-track betting and bingo during the year.

Based on available funds and an estimated number of properties qualifying for the credit, DOR determines a maximum credit value (MCV). The credit amount for each qualifying property is then calculated by multiplying the MCV (or the actual value of the property if that value is less than the MCV) by the applicable school tax rate. This is the amount of credit provided for that property. (sec. 79.10(9)(bm), (11), Wis. Stats.)

Q: Does a manufactured/mobile home that pays a monthly permit fee qualify?
A: Yes. It qualifies if the owner uses the manufactured/mobile home as their primary residence as of January 1 of the year the permit fees are applied. The municipal clerk calculates and deducts one-twelfth of the credit each month from the monthly municipal permit fee. Eligible manufactured/mobile home owners must file a lottery and gaming credit application with the municipal treasurer or the first class city treasurer (City of Milwaukee) to receive the credit. (secs. 79.10(1)(dm), (9)(bm), (10)(a), 66.0435(3)(c)1.c., Wis. Stats.)

Q: Did I receive the lottery and gaming credit?
A: To see if you received the credit, review your property tax bill. The lottery and gaming credit is located below the "Total (tax)" and First Dollar Credit lines on your tax bill. If an amount is listed on this line, the property received the credit.

Q: What if the lottery and gaming credit isn't listed on my tax bill?
A: If you are eligible for the credit as of the January 1 certification date, but your property tax bill does not list the credit, you must file a late claim application with DOR by October 1 after your tax bill is issued. Under state law, a taxpayer may only claim the previous year's missing lottery and gaming credit (sec. 79.10(10)(bm), Wis. Stats.). (Example: If your 2023 tax bill issued in Dec 2023 does not show the credit, you have until Oct 1, 2024 to file a late claim and receive the credit.)

Q: What if I purchased my home after January 1?
A: *(Typically, lottery credit eligibility is determined by ownership and primary residence status on January 1. If you purchase after that date, the credit for that year would have been claimed by the prior owner if eligible. You would qualify the next year if it's your primary residence.)*

Q: What happens if a property qualifying for the lottery and gaming credit is sold after January 1?
A: *(The credit remains on the property for that tax year; the new owner would not get a new credit for that year if the seller already claimed it, but the new owner should ensure to apply for the credit for the next year if it is their primary residence.)*

Q: Can I claim more than one lottery and gaming credit?
A: No. You may claim only one lottery and gaming credit, as it is limited to your primary residence.

Q: Who do I let know if a property no longer qualifies for the lottery and gaming credit?
A: Notify your county treasurer (or city treasurer if in a first-class city) if a property no longer qualifies (for example, if it is no longer your primary residence).

Q: What happens if I split my property during the year and the municipal or county treasurer prepares an assessment of a divided parcel (sec. 70.323, Wis. Stats.)?
A: *(Likely, each resulting parcel's qualification for the credit would depend on use as a primary residence. The specific handling may involve prorating or ensuring that any new parcel that is a primary residence gets the credit while others do not.)*

Q: What if I build a new home?
A: If you build a new home and it becomes your primary residence as of January 1 of the tax year, you can claim the lottery and gaming credit on it. You would need to apply for the credit with your local treasurer.

Q: Can I receive the lottery and gaming credit, and the First Dollar Credit?
A: Yes. If you qualify, you can receive both credits on the same property. The Lottery and Gaming Credit is for primary residences, and the First Dollar Credit applies to any property with a real property improvement. Many homeowners receive both on their tax bill.

Q: Do I qualify for the lottery and gaming credit if I hold a Life Estate?
A: Generally, the life tenant (person holding the life estate) is considered the owner for purposes of the lottery credit, and if it’s their primary residence, it qualifies for the credit.

Q: Do I qualify for the lottery and gaming credit if I am buying the property on a land contract?
A: Yes, if you are the buyer in a land contract and the property is your primary residence as of January 1, you can claim the lottery credit (you are considered the equitable owner).

Q: Do I qualify for the lottery and gaming credit if I am the beneficiary of a property that is in a trust?
A: If you occupy the property as your primary residence and are the beneficiary of a trust that owns the property, you may qualify. Typically, trustees can apply on behalf of eligible beneficiaries occupying the property.

Q: I didn't receive the lottery and gaming credit on my property tax bill for previous years. Can I apply for the lottery and gaming credit refund for those years?
A: You can only claim the credit for the immediate prior year by filing a late claim with DOR by October 1 of the year following the tax bill. You cannot go back multiple years for a refund; only the year immediately preceding.

Q: Who should I contact if I have additional Qs?
A: If your property is outside the City of Milwaukee, contact your county treasurer. If it is within the City of Milwaukee, contact the City of Milwaukee treasurer. For general filing Qs, review the instructions or contact DOR at (608) 266-0772 or (608) 266-9457.

Q: What property tax credits are available in Wisconsin?
A:
A property owner may qualify for several different types of credits:
- Wisconsin has credits that are applied directly to a property tax bill if the property or owner qualifies and/or applies for the credit (see Q 2)
- Wisconsin also has income tax credits designed to help offset property taxes, available for qualifying property owners when they complete their Wisconsin income tax return (see Q 3)
- Some homeowners may qualify for special loans to help pay property taxes (see Q 4)

Q: What credits are directly applied to my property tax bill?
A:
**Lottery and Gaming Credit** – If you are a Wisconsin resident, own your property and it is your primary residence, the property may qualify for this credit. (For more information, see Lottery and Gaming Credit FAQ.) This credit amount is listed on the property tax bill's "Lottery and Gaming Credit" line.

**First Dollar Credit** – If there is a real property improvement on the land, the property qualifies for the First Dollar Credit. (For more information, see First Dollar Credit FAQ.) This credit amount is listed on the property tax bill's "First Dollar Credit" line.

**School Levy Tax Credit** – All taxable real property in Wisconsin qualifies for the School Levy Tax Credit. This credit amount is listed on the property tax bill below the "Net Assessed Value Rate" box.

For more information on property tax credits listed on the tax bill, contact DOR at (608) 266-9457 or through their "Submit a Q" form.

Q: What credits can I claim on my income tax return?
A:
If you qualify, you may claim the following credits on your Wisconsin income tax return (check the income tax instructions and FAQs for qualifications):
- **Homestead Credit** – provides direct relief to low/moderate-income homeowners and renters (see Homestead Credit FAQ; information and email at dorhomesteadcredit@wisconsin.gov).
- **Farmland Preservation Credit** – available for farmers meeting certain requirements (see Farmland Preservation Credit FAQ; admin by Wisconsin DATCP, email dorfarmlandpreservationcredit@wisconsin.gov).
- **Veterans and Surviving Spouses Property Tax Credit** – available to qualifying veterans or their surviving spouses (see Veterans Property Tax Credit FAQ; email income@wisconsin.gov).
- **Renter's and Homeowner's School Property Tax Credit** – available on the income tax return for a portion of property taxes or rent constituting property taxes (contact income@wisconsin.gov for info).

Q: Are there other programs that help with paying property taxes?
A:
Yes. The Wisconsin Housing and Economic Development Authority (WHEDA) provides property tax deferral loans for the elderly. For more information, contact WHEDA:

WHEDA, PO Box 1728, Madison, WI 53701-1728, (800) 755-7835, Email: underwriting@wheda.com

Q: How is the school levy tax credit calculated?
A:
Formula for calculating the school levy tax credit:

Municipality's 3-Year Average School Levies / Statewide 3-Year Average School Levies x Total Funding = Municipality's Credit

*Example:* If a municipality’s 3-year average school levies are 7,960,546 and the statewide 3-year average is 5,559,570,121, and total funding is $1,275,000,000, then:

Municipality’s credit = (7,960,546 / 5,559,570,121) x 1,275,000,000 = $1,825,626 (approx.)

*Note:* The total funding changed effective for 2025 from $1,195,000,000 to $1,275,000,000.

Q: Is the school levy tax credit paid to the school district?
A: No. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) distributes this credit to counties and municipalities. DOR makes the payments to the county where the municipality is located and then the county distributes the payment to the municipality. (Note: DOR can make payments directly to a municipality if it qualifies for an exception and follows the requirements under state law, sec. 79.10(7m)(cm), Wis. Stats.)

Q: When are towns, villages and cities notified of the school levy tax credit amount?
A: DOR must inform municipalities of their school levy tax credit payments on or before November 20 each year. (sec. 79.10(2), Wis. Stats.)

Q: How is the school levy tax credit reported on individual property tax bills?
A:
On property tax bills, school tax levies are reported after subtracting the school levy tax credits. The amount of the school levy tax credit for the current year is listed in a separate box on each property tax bill.

The credit is calculated for each individual tax bill as:

(Total municipality's school levy tax credit / Final Statement of Assessment for municipality) x the property's assessed value on the tax bill = School Levy Tax Credit for that property.

*Example:* If a municipality has $81,293.86 in total school levy credit and a Final SOA total value of $78,419,700, and a given property is assessed at $332,100, then that property’s credit = (81,293.86 / 78,419,700) x 332,100 = ~$344.27.

*Note:* The final SOA must equal the total value of all school districts (K-12 plus K-8) within the municipality.

Q: How does a property owner qualify for the school levy tax credit?
A: The school levy tax credit is applied to every taxable property. The credit amount is based on the property's assessed value as a percent of the municipality's total assessed value. There is no special application; every property automatically receives it based on value.

Q: Zoning requires a minimum of five acres to split off as a residential parcel. Can I use that acreage requirement as the land "necessary for the location and convenience" of the agricultural improvements, when the agricultural buildings include a residence?
A: No. Even though the minimum residential parcel size may be five acres, if all or part of the land is primarily devoted to a qualifying agricultural use under administrative rule (sec. Tax 【10†18†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Adm. Code), the qualifying acreage is classified as agricultural. Actual acreage devoted to the farm site (collection of agricultural buildings, including the residence) should be determined independently for each parcel. Acreage use, not zoning, is the determining factor.

Q: A 40-acre parcel classified as agricultural (class 4) in 2024 is sold during that year. The property was re-zoned residential, and a subdivision approval was granted before January 1, 2025. As of June 2025, the parcel was covered with last year's crop stubble. Do the earlier activities indicating a future use change and the lack of use in agricultural meet the rule's criteria of "incompatible with agricultural use?"
A: This parcel does not become incompatible with agricultural use based solely on the legal changes (rezoning and subdivision approval). Even the presence of survey stakes may not stop a farmer from producing and harvesting an agricultural crop. Since the land was in an agricultural use during the production season before the January 1, 2025 assessment date, its classification on the January 1, 2025 assessment roll remains agricultural.

Q: Can a municipality pass an ordinance against using land for agricultural purposes, which in effect would disallow agricultural classification of that land?
A: A municipality may pass such an ordinance. The legality of the ordinance and its enforcement is case-specific. Land must be classified as agricultural if it was devoted primarily to a qualifying agricultural use under administrative rule (sec. Tax 【10†18†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Adm. Code) during the prior production season and was compatible with agricultural use on January 1 of the current assessment year. Even if in violation of an ordinance, easement, or contract, the agricultural classification applies until the land is no longer devoted primarily to a qualifying agricultural use.

Q: Should land actively used for agricultural purposes, in violation of a local ordinance prohibiting agricultural use, still be classified as agricultural?
A: Yes. Since state law supersedes local ordinances, this land is classified as agricultural because it meets the definition of agricultural use under sec. Tax 【10†18†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Adm. Code. Enforcement of the ordinance is a municipal issue. Once the land is no longer used for agricultural purposes (either through enforcement or landowner choice), the classification must be changed. (Land must be classified as agricultural if it was devoted primarily to a qualifying agricultural use in the prior production season and was compatible with agricultural use on January 1. Even if in violation for the current year, the classification stays agricultural until the use changes.)

Q: Is land enrolled in the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) considered an agricultural use?
A: Yes. Administrative rule (sec. Tax 【10†18†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Adm. Code) lists enrollment in CRP as an agricultural use. However, land removed from the CRP program may now be incompatible with agricultural use (e.g., if it has succeeded to woodland) and may need to be reclassified and valued appropriately. For more information on programs qualifying for agricultural classification, see the 【11†Tax 18 Publication】.

Q: Can land enrolled in other programs be considered an agricultural use?
A: Lands in other programs may qualify; see the 【11†Tax 18 Publication】. Note: If land is devoted primarily to an agricultural use under sec. Tax 【12†18.05(1)(a)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, 【12†(b)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, or 【12†(c)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】 during the prior production season and is not in a use incompatible with agriculture on the assessment date, it may qualify for agricultural classification. In essence, the land may qualify for use-value assessment based on how it was used, not merely what program it’s in.

Q: When is forest land properly classified as pasture land?
A: Pastured woods devoted primarily to agricultural use (keeping, grazing, or feeding livestock) qualify for agricultural classification. Active grazing keeps the undergrowth down. A few paths through the woods are not enough evidence of active pasture. The land must be pastured regularly. There should be fencing preventing animals from straying. Land with little to no vegetation isn't considered pasture. (Definitions: see the Wisconsin Property Assessment Manual – pasture vs. forest – and the 【13†Agricultural Assessment Guide for Wisconsin Property Owners】.)

Q: Are small parcels of land eligible for agricultural classification?
A: Yes. Size is not a factor by itself. Even a small acreage (e.g., a 5-acre apple orchard or a small vegetable plot) can be primarily devoted to agricultural use and thus be classified agricultural. What matters is that the land was primarily used for an agricultural purpose (as defined in sec. 【15†Tax 18.05(1)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】) during the year prior to the assessment and not put to an incompatible use by January 1. Assessors should not use arbitrary size thresholds; they must consider the actual use of each parcel individually.

Q: What is the proper classification for each of the following parcels? (Example scenario of a farm being developed into a subdivision with various parcels A, B, C, etc.)
A:
*(Summarized from example)*
- **Parcel A:** 5 acres (2 acres crops harvested last fall, remainder wooded). Classify 2 acres agricultural, rest residential (wooded area considered part of likely residential lot).
- **Parcel B:** 5 acres (2-acre field extension of A's field, 3 acres fallow tillable). Classify part agricultural (the 2-acre field) and part residential (the fallow land, since it's in a subdivision with infrastructure, sale as residential imminent, typical residential size).
- **Parcel C:** 4 acres (house, 3 acres trees, 1 acre ag field part of farm operation). Classify 1 acre agricultural, balance residential (house site and woods supporting residential use).
- **Parcel D:** 5 acres (mostly woods, 1 acre fallow, house). Classify entirely residential (no active ag; fallow portion is part of subdivision with imminent home construction).
- **Parcel E:** 5 acres (2 acres fallow field, 3 acres woods). Classify entirely residential (no qualifying ag use, in subdivision context similar to D).
- **Parcel F:** 5 acres (all farmed last year, no buildings). Classify agricultural (in active crop use, qualifies for use-value assessment).
- **Parcel G:** 5 acres (adjacent to F, all woods). Classify residential (in subdivision, no ag, infrastructure in place, etc.).
- **Parcel H:** 5 acres (all woods, next to G, adjacent to I which is fallow). Classify residential (similar reasoning as G).
- **Parcel I:** 5 acres (fallow, adjacent to H). Classify residential (no current ag, part of subdivision).

Q: How are site acres of other (class 7) determined? How does a property owner appeal the assessor's determination of the size of the farm site?
A: Per state law, the land necessary for the location and convenience of the farm home and farm buildings is classified as other (class 7). To determine the site acreage, the assessor should use aerial photos and scale out the area actually used for the buildings. If a property owner disagrees with the determined site acres, they should bring credible evidence (e.g., a certified survey map, updated aerial photo, other documentation) to the assessor and, if needed, to Open Book or Board of Review.

Q: How is the classification of other (class 7) improvements determined? What factors are used to make this determination? Is it proper to classify a set of improvements by listing the agricultural outbuildings as other (class 7) and the residence as residential (class 1)?
A: Generally, improvements should be classified as other (class 7) when the predominant use of the building set is agricultural. Factors include current use, potential use, number and significance of outbuildings, parcel size, and the nature of the agricultural buildings supporting the farm. Assessors should classify a set of buildings with a single class based on the predominant use of the entire set, rather than splitting the class of buildings. However, state law (sec. 【16†70.32(2)(c)1m†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】) allows an assessor to classify a typical farm residential building set as "other" if the residence is used by the farm operator's spouse, children, parents, or grandparents, and the residence is on land that is part of the farm operation.

Q: How should the site acres for other (class 7) lands be valued? Should they be valued as one- or two-acre parcels? Should the fact that the site is part of a larger parcel be considered?
A: Land necessary for the location and convenience of buildings should be valued at its contributory market value, adjusted to the overall assessment level of the municipality. Each improved agricultural site must be analyzed for how many acres are needed for the buildings. Some sites with extensive buildings may need more acres; others less. Assessors should not assume the same site size for all farms in the town. When valuing the site, consider its contribution to the total parcel's value, not as if it's always a fixed 1 or 2 acres independent of the farm.

Q: How should an assessor classify tillable land where the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources purchased an easement that does not allow tilling or grazing the land?
A: If the land is enrolled in a qualifying government program under administrative rule (sec. Tax 【15†18.05(1)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】), it should be classified as agricultural and placed in the sub-class it would be if farmed (e.g., tillable). If it does not qualify (no ag use due to easement), its class must change to something else – likely undeveloped (5), agricultural forest (5m), or productive forest (6) – and then valued at market value (considering any easement effect on value). Then those values are adjusted to 50% for classes 5 and 5m (undeveloped/ag forest) and all classes adjusted to the community’s average assessment level. (Land must remain classified agricultural if it was devoted primarily to ag use in the prior year and was compatible on Jan 1, even if an easement is in place, until it is no longer devoted to ag use.)

Q: How is a 20-acre parcel with a one-acre building site and 19 acres of grazing area for a horse classified? Are the 19 acres considered an agricultural use?
A:
- Keeping a horse for personal use or boarding horses does NOT meet the definition of agricultural use under sec. Tax 【15†18.05†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Adm. Code. Some activities might look agricultural but don't fit the defined categories (by rule, things like training race horses, riding stables, rental of saddle horses, operating a racetrack are considered recreation, not agriculture).
- Raising horses under NAICS 112920 (i.e., operations that provide foal rearing, health maintenance, controlled feeding and harvest for eventual sale) is considered an agricultural use.
- Renting land to a horse owner may appear to be pasture, but if the land isn't being used for an agricultural purpose as defined above, it is not eligible for agricultural classification.

*(So in the example, if the horse grazing is just personal or boarding and not part of an agricultural enterprise like horse breeding for sale, the land would not be agricultural. Likely the 19 acres would be classified as residential or other, not agricultural.)*

Q: A person bought a parcel of agricultural and forest land during 2024 for substantially more than the 2024 assessment. The municipality was revalued in 2025. For 2025, the assessor assessed the agricultural land using the published 2025 use values. The remaining forest land was assessed using the 2024 selling price minus the 2025 use value of the agricultural lands. Was this correct?
A: No. The sale should be analyzed by determining the contributory market value of each component (ag land vs. other land). After finding the market value portion for each component, the non-agricultural land should be assessed per normal market valuation rules. The tillable and pasture land were correctly assessed at use-value for 2025. However, the assessor should not simply subtract the use-value from the sale price to derive the other land's value. The forest (non-ag) land must be assessed at market value in line with statutory provisions, independent of the use-value calculation for the ag part.

Q: Is there a conversion charge for converting agricultural land to another use?
A:
- Yes. Property no longer used for agricultural purposes that benefited from lower taxes due to ag classification is subject to a conversion charge if the use changes to residential, commercial or manufacturing.
- However, if ag land is converted to another use and becomes exempt, the assessor must consider what its classification would be if it were not exempt to decide if a conversion fee applies. No conversion charge if the land meets the definition of and is classified as undeveloped, agricultural forest, productive forest, or "other" (e.g., farm home site).
- The assessor makes the determination on the following year's roll. The conversion charge per acre decreases as the acreage converted increases (more acres = lower $ per acre). For more information, see the **common Qs for agricultural land conversion charge** (DOR FAQ).

Q: Can Board of Review (BOR) members view the property in person to determine whether a piece of property is used for pasture, rather than woods?
A: No. The BOR may only act on sworn evidence presented to it. The BOR can change a classification (and value) if sworn testimony or evidence at the hearing supports that action. Under state law (sec. 【18†70.47†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】, Wis. Stats.), the BOR can only act on evidence under oath. (They cannot independently go inspect the property as part of the hearing deliberation process.)

Q: Is maple sap gathering considered an agricultural activity, and if so, how should this type of land be assessed?
A: Yes. By administrative rule, maple sap gathering is a qualifying agricultural use (NAICS includes it as crop production). Land devoted primarily to tapping maple trees for sap during the season before the assessment and not put to a conflicting use by January 1 is classified as agricultural and assessed at its use value. There is no minimum acreage; even small tracts can qualify if primarily used for maple sap. The key is that the area of woods is sufficiently tapped per industry standards (roughly at least 20 tapped maples per acre in mixed woods, 30-40 per acre in high-quality maple stands). A forest area with no or very minimal tapping does not qualify. Occasional or minimal tapping over a large area and claiming the whole as ag does not qualify; the activity must be bona fide and significant in that area.

Q: Are licensed game farms considered an agricultural use?
A: The NAICS classifies game farms, fishing preserves, hunting preserves, and game propagation under Fishing, Hunting and Trapping industries – not agriculture. So land used for those is classified by its actual use (possibly commercial or forest) and valued at market. However, operations for deer farming (raising deer for eventual sale – i.e. NAICS livestock farming) can be agricultural. If fenced land is devoted primarily to deer production, it is agricultural land (categorized as grade 1, 2, 3 or pasture based on soil).

Q: Is aquaculture an agricultural use?
A: Land devoted primarily to animal aquaculture (fish farming) qualifies as agricultural use under sec. Tax 【10†18.05(1)(b)†docs.legis.wisconsin.gov】 (Animal Production). These are operations that actively manage breeding, feeding, and health of fish. An outdoor fish pond used to raise fish for market is considered akin to pasture (as land supporting animal production) and can be classified as agricultural. However, not all aquaculture facilities qualify: concrete raceways, indoor hatcheries, etc., do not meet the definition of "land...devoted primarily to agricultural use" (they're structures/improvements). Also, recreational ponds or personal-use ponds do not qualify.

Q: Is cranberry production an agricultural use?
A: Yes. Land under cranberry beds is devoted primarily to an agricultural use. It should be classified as agricultural and typically categorized as third-grade tillable, then adjusted to the local assessment level. Note: Land under related earthen structures (dams, dikes, ditches, inlets, outlets around the beds) is classed as "other" (class 7) and assessed at the third-grade tillable value (again adjusted to local level). The earthen structures themselves are valued via cost less depreciation.

Q: Is nursery stock production an agricultural use?
A: Yes. NAICS 111421 (nursery and floriculture production) covers growing nursery products, stock, shrubbery, bulbs, sod, etc., which is crop production and thus agriculture. Also, state law now specifically includes growing short rotation woody crops (harvest cycle 10 years or less for pulp/biomass) as agriculture. (Just occasionally harvesting a few trees on one's land, however, is not primarily an agricultural use.)

Q: How are agricultural use-values determined?
A: DOR annually publishes use-values for tillable grades 1, 2, 3 and pasture land. DOR uses a formula based on the income approach: income is derived from crop-share agreements (which net out certain farming costs) and corn yield data. Use-values are calculated for each municipality in each county. Annual changes in use-value are capped by the statewide change in equalized value, minus growth from new construction and minus the change in overall ag land value. See the Wisconsin Property Assessment Manual (WPAM) Chapter 14, Appendix B for details.

Q: How does an assessor know if acreage is enrolled in a program eligible for agricultural classification if the land is not currently being used for agriculture?
A: The assessor should directly inquire. They can call, email, or send an "Agricultural Classification Conservation Program Information Request" (Form PR-324) to owners of parcels that appear Qable (no obvious ag use visible). This form or outreach helps determine if the owner has the land in a qualifying conservation program that would allow agricultural classification even if the land isn't actively farmed that year.

Q: How should the phrase "production season" as specified in administrative rule (sec. Tax 18.06(1), Wis. Adm. Code) be applied in determining eligibility for agricultural use valuation?
A: "Production season" generally means the period from spring through fall when typical farming activities occur. This phrase provides a standard for assessors to judge if land was "primarily devoted" to ag use. Most agricultural uses in Wisconsin occur during this growing season. If there is an agricultural use that occurs outside the typical season (e.g., winter-only use), those cases are rare and should be discussed between the owner and assessor. Usually, land needs to be in ag use during the normal growing season. If land is only used very briefly outside the normal season, the assessor must look carefully at whether that constitutes its primary use. In general, if land is only used for ag for a minimal time outside spring-fall, and not at all during spring-fall, it likely wouldn't qualify as primarily devoted to agriculture.

Q: How is the conversion charge calculated?
A:
The number of acres converted is multiplied by a per-acre value for each converted acre. That per-acre value is calculated in two steps:
1. First, find the difference between the county’s average fair market value of agricultural land (based on prior year sales of 38+ acre ag land) and the county’s average equalized value per acre of agricultural land (its use-value).
2. Then apply a conversion size factor:
   - If >30 acres are converted, multiply the difference by 5% to get the charge per acre.
   - If 10 to 30 acres, multiply difference by 7.5%.
   - If <10 acres, multiply difference by 10%.

*Example 1:* County avg market value/acre for ag land = $5,490; county avg use-value/acre = $210; difference = $5,280.
Conversion charge per acre = $264 if >30 acres (5% of 5,280), $396 if 10-30 acres (7.5%), $528 if <10 acres (10%).

*Example 2:* If 1.33 acres are converted (<10), charge = $528 * 1.33 = $702. (When totaling acres, combine all acres owned by the same entity in the same municipality converting that year.)

See DOR's **Agricultural Land Conversion Charge Guidelines** for per-acre charges by acreage band. (No charge if the computed per-acre charge would be < $25.)

Q: If a parcel is split, how is the size calculated when determining which conversion charge to apply?
A: The conversion charge is based on change of use, not merely reclassification. If ag land is subdivided into lots and reclassified as residential (but still actively farmed at the moment), strictly splitting doesn't trigger the charge until the use actually changes. The total acres that change use in a year (under the same ownership in a municipality) determine the acreage bracket for the charge percentage.

Q: Who issues the conversion charge?
A: The county treasurer issues the conversion charge as a special charge on the property tax bill of the converted land, once notified by the assessor’s report (on the assessment roll) of the change in use.

Q: When are the values used in the conversion charge calculation available?
A: The average fair market value of ag land and average use-value (needed for the calc) are typically available annually after the prior year’s sales are analyzed. DOR usually provides these figures in the summer or early fall to use for that year’s charges.

Q: Are there exceptions to a conversion charge?
A: Yes. No charge applies if the per-acre charge would compute to less than $25. Also, conversions to certain exempt or other agricultural classes (undeveloped, ag forest, productive forest, “other”) are not charged unless they later convert to a developed class.

Q: If land converts to undeveloped land (class 5), agricultural forest (class 5m), productive forest (class 6) or other (class 7) for one year, and then converts to residential (class 1), is it then liable for a conversion charge?
A: If the land’s use fundamentally changed from agriculture to a use that is still taxed (like undeveloped or forest) and then to residential, the conversion charge applies at the point it changes to a developed class (residential). However, if it stayed in another open-space class for one year then went residential, the assessor at the time of change to residential would issue the charge.

Q: What is the definition of "other" as a category on the roll?
A: "Other" (class 7) is essentially farm buildings and improvements site – the land necessary for farmstead buildings (farm home and outbuildings) and improvements that is not otherwise classified.

Q: Does "other" include a residential home built on five acres split off a tilled 40-acre parcel as a separate parcel if the ownership changed to the farm operator's children, parents, or grandparents before the change in use took place?
A: Under sec. 70.32(2)(c)1m, if a parcel with a residence is owned by the children, parents, or grandparents of the farm operator, it can be classified as "other" rather than residential, provided it’s part of the farm operation land. Once it’s truly split off and not part of the farm, it would become residential, but if done beforehand, it might be classed as other until use changes.

Q: Does the assessor have to reclassify all residential parcels belonging to children, parents, or grandparents of farm operators to "other"?
A: The assessor should apply class 7 "other" to those qualifying family-occupied farm residences as allowed by law. It’s not automatic – the parcel must be part of the farm operation and meet the criteria (family relationship and use as part of farm). If so, yes, classify as other rather than residential.

Q: An existing farm operation with the majority of its land classified agricultural tears some buildings down, adds some additional buildings, and changes the total area used for the site. Does a conversion charge apply?
A: If the farm site area expands into land that was previously agricultural land (tilling/pasture) to accommodate new buildings, that land is now classed "other" (farm site). That is a conversion of use from agricultural to other (class 7). However, conversions to class 7 do **not** trigger a conversion fee, because "other" is one of the exempted classes (conversion charge is only if going to residential, commercial, manufacturing).

Q: A parcel was classified as nine acres agricultural and one acre of land and buildings classified as "other" on the January 1, 2023 assessment roll. The parcel had new construction during 2023. Three additional agricultural acres were converted to site acres, and the improvement's highest and best use changed to residential.
