The assessor did not discover the changes until after the 2024 assessment was completed. The 2024 taxes reflected only the original "other" site and improvements from 2023. For the January 1, 2025 assessment, the parcel was reclassified as residential, with a significantly higher improvement value. Does a conversion charge apply?
A: Yes, likely. In 2025 the land use had clearly changed (farm land became part of an expanded home site and the improvement became residential use). Once the assessor reclassifies to residential, a conversion charge is due on the acres that were ag in 2023 and have now become part of the residential site. The fact it was missed in 2024 means it’s caught up in 2025; the charge would be calculated on the acres converted to non-ag use (the three acres) using the values in effect. The delay doesn’t avoid the charge.

Q: What should an assessor do when discovering land was misclassified?
A: They should correct the classification on the next assessment roll and, if it resulted in a conversion (ag to developed use), report it so the conversion charge can be issued. If the misclassification resulted in omitted tax or overpaid tax, they might also need to handle it via correction of error procedures or inform the municipality for a chargeback if taxes were refunded.

Q: Is land previously classified as agricultural that is left fallow, subject to a conversion charge?
A: If land simply lies fallow but isn’t put to a non-ag use and remains owned by the same person, it’s usually still considered agricultural (fallow land is still agricultural if it's part of normal crop rotation or temporary). Just being fallow is not a conversion if the intent/use is still agricultural. A conversion fee would not apply unless it was actually changed to a developed use (residential/commercial etc.).

Q: If the property was classified agricultural on January 1 and entered in the Managed Forest Law (MFL) program during that year (becoming exempt on the assessment roll), is a conversion charge due?
A: No, because MFL land is exempt. Also, conversion charges are not applied when ag land becomes exempt forest (the law specifically only charges for conversions to residential, commercial, manufacturing). However, the assessor would note its change for classification purposes.

Q: What if I disagree with the property's change in classification?
A: You can appeal the assessor’s classification. First, discuss with the assessor. If unresolved, you can object to the classification before the Board of Review. If still unsatisfied after BOR, further appeal to DOR under sec. 70.85 or to circuit court can be options depending on the situation.

Q: When is the conversion charge due?
A: It’s included as a special charge on the property’s tax bill for the year of conversion. That tax bill is due with the usual property tax due dates (Jan 31 or installments). Essentially, when the land is converted and noted on the Jan 1 assessment, the charge gets billed in December of that year on the tax bill, due the following January.

Q: If a change in use takes place, and a conversion charge is due, but no conversion charge is issued, can a county treasurer issue the conversion charge in the following years?
A: If it was missed, the treasurer can still collect it later once discovered (similar to how omitted taxes can be picked up). However, ideally the charge is placed on the very next bill after conversion. If not, there might be procedures to issue it later, but it’s complicated; better to catch it timely.

Q: Who owes the conversion charge?
A: The owner of the property at the time the tax bill with the charge is issued is responsible for paying it (just like property taxes). Essentially, it’s attached to the land, so the current owner gets the bill.

Q: How are buyers being made aware of the potential conversion charge?
A: Ideally through disclosure: the conversion charge is recorded as a special charge on tax bills if triggered. Also, Wisconsin law requires that offers to purchase agricultural land include a notice about the potential conversion charge. Title companies and realtors often alert buyers if land is subject to use-value recapture (conversion charge) risk.

Q: What if the conversion charge is not paid?
A: It is treated like a delinquent property tax. Unpaid conversion charges will accrue interest/penalties and can eventually lead to tax delinquency proceedings (including tax certificate and foreclosure) if not paid.

Q: Can the county subtract the administrative costs of collection from the conversion charge amount returned to the taxation districts?
A: No, the law doesn’t provide for the county to skim administrative costs from the collected conversion charge. The collected charge is apportioned to the underlying taxing jurisdictions per statute without an administrative fee.

Q: Does the county share the 1% per month added interest payment 50/50 with the municipality, or does the county keep that income?
A: Typically, for delinquent taxes, the interest/penalties might be apportioned by state law (often counties retain some portion for costs). For conversion charges, since treated as tax, the interest on delinquent special charges might be retained by the county similar to delinquent tax interest distribution rules. (This might be detailed in statutes – likely the county keeps the interest since they bear the collection responsibility.)

Q: Once a conversion charge becomes a special charge on the tax bill, can a county add its 0.5% tax to the bill, like with "other" special charges?
A: Usually, counties cannot add extra fees beyond what the statute authorizes. The 0.5% county sales tax does not apply to property tax bills. Perhaps this is referring to interest on specials – but if it’s a special charge, the county can’t tack on a sales tax. So no, the county’s 0.5% sales tax has nothing to do with the property tax bill or special charges.

Q: Do the overlying taxation jurisdictions share in the conversion charge?
A: Yes. When a conversion charge is collected, it is ultimately returned proportionally to the other taxing jurisdictions (county, school, technical college, etc.) based on how the tax levy was shared, after first reimbursing the state for its portion (if any). Essentially it reverses the original distribution of tax on that land.

Q: Are exempt entities (e.g., churches and benevolent associations) subject to the conversion charge?
A: Yes, if they convert ag land to an exempt use, the conversion charge still applies because it’s based on the change of use from agricultural. Even if the new owner is exempt from future property taxes, the charge for the prior benefit of use-value still applies.

Q: Are governmental entities subject to the conversion charge under state law (sec. 74.485, Wis. Stats.)?
A: Yes, there’s no blanket exemption for government entities in the conversion charge statute. If a municipality or the state buys ag land and takes it to an exempt use, a conversion charge is due (though effectively one government paying another). There are some cases where if state condemns land, perhaps no charge, but generally yes, governments are not exempt.

Q: Can a conversion charge be issued more than once on the same parcel of land?
A: Yes, if the land cycles back into agriculture and again out to a developed use, theoretically a new conversion charge could apply for the new conversion. However, the statute prevents double-charging for the same conversion. But if, for example, part of a parcel converted one year (charge issued), and the remaining part converts later, that later part can incur its own charge.

Q: What is a chargeback of rescinded or refunded taxes?
A:
A municipality may request reimbursement ("chargeback") of property taxes it has refunded or rescinded to a property owner. If DOR approves the request, the other taxing jurisdictions must pay the municipality back for the amounts it had previously settled with them in the tax collection process. Requests must be e-filed using the Request for Chargeback of Rescinded or Refunded Taxes (Form PC-201). Before submitting to DOR:
- The property owner must have requested and received a refund of overpaid taxes (with any interest) from the municipality.
- The municipality must have actually refunded or rescinded those taxes to the owner.

Q: How do I file a chargeback of rescinded or refunded taxes?
A: You must e-file Form PC-201 (Request for Chargeback of Rescinded or Refunded Taxes) via MyDORGov. (See DOR’s Online Filing Help for using My DOR Government Account.)

Q: Do I need a PIN number or password to file a chargeback request?
A: The request is filed in MyDORGov. You need to be an authorized user for the municipality’s account to file. (Refer to Online Filing Help – Using My DOR Government Account for details on access.)

Q: What are the requirements for submitting a request for chargeback of rescinded or refunded taxes to the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR)?
A:
For refunds of taxes on or after Jan 1, 2018: the refunded tax for any single property (parcel) for one year must be $250 or more. You can include taxes from any of the five assessment years immediately preceding the year you submit the PC-201 (or from a court decision) as long as you submit within one year of that court decision.

For older assessments (Jan 1, 2017 and prior): the threshold was $500 per parcel or an aggregate of $5,000 of refunded taxes from that year for the district.

Note: The property owner must have actually received the refund (with interest, if applicable) before the chargeback request is sent to DOR.

Q: What if a municipality doesn't file the request by the October 1 deadline?
A: If the municipality misses the October 1 deadline for a given year, it may submit the request (Form PC-201) by October 1 of the next year. DOR will then treat it as a request in that next cycle, and make a determination by November 15 of that following year.

Q: When and who does DOR notify after making a determination?
A: After DOR processes chargeback requests received by October 1, we certify the chargeback amounts by November 15. DOR sends the municipal clerk a copy of the request form with our determination, showing the amount each taxing jurisdiction must pay. We also notify each affected taxing jurisdiction. (Even if DOR denies a request, the determination copy will show $0 for that jurisdiction, for record.)

Q: When do the affected taxing jurisdictions have to pay their amount of the chargeback to the municipality that filed the chargeback request?
A: Each taxing jurisdiction must pay the municipality by February 15 of the year following DOR's November determination.

Q: Does a Tax Incremental District have any effect on our chargeback determination made by DOR?
A: If the refunded/rescinded taxes were for property in a Tax Incremental District (TID), those taxes are not eligible for chargeback **unless** the TID’s current value is below its base value in the year of the refund. In other words, normally TID taxes can’t be charged back (because the city would eat it within the TID), except if the TID is distressed (value dropped below base).

Q: Does the chargeback amount have an effect on mill rate limits?
A: No. Under state law (sec. 74.41(6), Wis. Stats.), if a taxing jurisdiction levies tax to cover a chargeback it owes, that amount is excluded when calculating any statutory mill rate limit. It doesn’t count against their cap.

Q: What is a Preliminary Chargeback Determination memo, and why did I receive one?
A: DOR may send out a Preliminary Chargeback Determination memo to municipalities and taxing jurisdictions if a large chargeback request is being processed. This memo is basically a heads-up (preliminary approval) so that affected jurisdictions can budget for the amount they’ll owe. DOR still issues the official certification by November 15, and jurisdictions still pay by Feb 15 following – the preliminary memo just helps with budgeting.

Q: Do we need to issue bills to each taxing jurisdiction?
A: No. By November 15, DOR will notify each taxing jurisdiction of what they owe to the municipal treasurer by Feb 15. The municipal treasurer doesn’t have to send a bill; the jurisdictions are expected to pay based on DOR’s certification.

Q: How do we know what statute relates to the rescinded or refunded tax?
A: The assessor’s correction or the process that led to the refund should cite a statute. For example: sec. 70.511 (assessment objection settled in court), 74.33 (refund due to palpable error, etc.), 70.43 (corrected roll errors) etc. The assessor and clerk should identify under which statute the refund was made.

Q: Should I file Form PC-200 or PC-201?
A:
- File **Form PC-201** for chargeback of rescinded/refunded taxes under sec. 74.41, Wis. Stats. (that’s what we’ve been discussing). Due by Oct 1.
- File **Form PC-200** for chargeback of uncollected personal property taxes under sec. 74.42, Wis. Stats. This is a separate process for when personal property taxes are delinquent and meet certain criteria (business closed, bankrupted, property removed). PC-200 is filed between Feb 2 and Apr 1 of the year following the tax became delinquent.

*(Note: As of 2024, Act 12 exempted most personal property from taxes, so PC-200 will be phased out after 2025.)*

Q: Are there additional resources for the chargeback process?
A: Yes. See **Publication PA-600** (Property Tax Refund Requests and the Chargeback Process) for detailed guidance.

Q: What do we report on the Statement of Assessment (SOA) Line 23?
A: Report only assessed value changes due to sec. 70.43 corrections of errors by assessors. If an assessed value was reduced, report it as a negative number. If increased, report as a positive number.

Q: What do we report on the Statement of Taxes (SOT) Section I?
A: Report only the additional tax amounts or refunded tax amounts due to sec. 70.43 assessor error corrections. Additional taxes (if any) are a positive amount. Refunded or rescinded taxes are a negative amount.

Q: How do we know if our municipality has a chargeback?
A: Review state law sec. 74.41 or check if your clerk submitted any Form PC-201 by Oct 1. Additionally, DOR’s determination letter by Nov 15 would inform you. Basically, unless you applied, you won’t have one; if you did, DOR’s response tells you.

Q: How do we calculate the refund after the BOR certifies the value of the assessor's correction?
A: If a Board of Review under sec. 70.43 certifies a value change due to assessor error, the refund to the taxpayer (and thus the chargeback amount) is the difference in taxes resulting from the value correction, plus interest if applicable (interest usually 0.8% per month from the date of payment, if refunded after Feb 1).

Q: Do we need to refund interest?
A: Yes, if a taxpayer is owed a refund of taxes (like due to a 70.43 correction or court order) and it’s after a certain date (usually February 1), the law often requires interest be paid to the taxpayer. The interest is typically 0.8% per month from the date the tax was paid until the refund date. The interest paid is also included in what can be charged back to the other jurisdictions.

Q: With the exemption of all locally assessed and manufacturing personal property effective January 1, 2024, can we still charge back personal property?
A: For taxes as of 2024 onward, there will be no locally assessed personal property taxes (Act 12). So going forward, Form PC-200 will be obsolete because new personal property delinquency situations won’t occur. However, if there are still delinquent personal property taxes from 2022 or 2023 that meet criteria, you could still file PC-200 up through 2025.

Q: When is the filing deadline for MFR?
A:
Municipalities and counties with a population:
- 2,500 or less  March 31
- Over 2,500  May 1
- Extended due date for all municipalities and counties  May 15 (no request required)
Municipalities and counties with a population over 25,000:
- July 31  must also submit an auditor's opinion (Administrative Rule Tax 16.05) with a final version of the Financial Report
- To submit the auditor's opinion (Administrative Rule Tax 16), you must e-file an amended financial report and attach the auditor's opinion
- Auditor's opinion must indicate whether the information submitted is a clear representation of the municipality's or county's audited financial statements

Q: How are municipalities and counties notified that the MFR form is available for filing?
A:
In early February, DOR notifies each county and municipality by email that the Municipal Financial Report Forms are available in MyDORGov. The email includes the following information:
- Filing instructions
- State Payment Register  record of payments that Wisconsin state agencies made to Wisconsin municipalities and counties
- U.S. Census Bureau Form F-65  is available on our MFR web page

Q: What documents are required to complete this report?
A:
- Statement of Taxes (SOT)
- Tax District Treasurer's Settlement (Municipal Treasurer's Settlement)
- State Payment Register
- Your annual financial report
- Prior year fillings are located in MyDORGov under historical filings

Q: Will I be charged a penalty if I file this report late?
A:
Yes. If you do not file this report by May 15, state law (sec. 86.303(5)) requires a late filing penalty that reduces your General Transportation Aid payments from the Wisconsin Department of Transportation (DOT). This penalty is calculated and imposed by the DOT.
If DOR does not receive your report, we may request that a Certified Public Accountant compile the report from your municipal or county records. Your municipality or county is billed directly for this cost.

Q: Can I amend the e-filed report?
A: Yes. You can file an amended report in My DOR Government Account . You may be required to provide additional information/documentation to support your amended return.

Q: Why are some values on the MFR auto-filled; can I change these values?
A:
Some auto-filled line values are transferred from other sources, other lines in the MFR form, or are carryover from the prior year. This makes it easier to complete the form, compare prior year data with the current year, and quickly identify large variances and possible errors.
Sources of auto-filled lines:
- DOR VAULT System
- Municipal Treasurer's Settlement (MTS)
- Statement of Taxes (SOT)
- State Payment Register
- Other lines in the current and prior MFR form
Auto-filled values can be changed, and if changed, a warning appears requiring an explanation or additional documentation to support the change.

Q: I'm having trouble with the Tax Roll Reconciliation page (Section B). What should I do?
A:
Review the Tax Roll Reconciliation Cash Basis Accounting instructions within the detailed form instructions .
In the e-file form:
- On the "Accounting Basis" section, make sure you selected "Cash Basis Accounting"
- Review your entries for errors
- Check beginning and ending balances of all accounts

Q: My report does not balance. What should I do?
A:
- Review all warning and errors; a list is provided on the last page of the form
- All errors must be corrected before submitting the form
- Check beginning and ending balances of all accounts
- Make sure all amounts from your accounts were correctly transferred to the form
- Make your financial account numbers match the MFR form. The form uses the Uniform Chart of Accounts .
- Make sure all the cash accounts are included in Section O of cash basis forms
- Avoid making large, unexplained entries on "Miscellaneous" lines of the form. Use the MFR instructions, linked on the right panel of the e-file form, to aid you in determining the correct line to use.
- Only comment on large variances or amounts updated by the preparer

Q: What type of  assessment information do I need to store electronically?
A:
- Required  you must electronically store all assessment data (ex: parcel attributes, sketches, and photographs)
- Excluded  information in assessment work files (ex: handwritten  notes, correspondence, building permits, or field sketches). An assessor may choose to maintain this information in an electronic format.

Q: What responsibility do assessors have to communicate this requirement to the municipality?
A: Assessors must communicate with the governing body, in writing, that the  required assessment data will be stored in an electronic format. The assessor  must also inform the governing body where the data will be located.

Q: When the municipality  hires a new assessor, who is responsible for the cost of transferring the electronically  stored data to the municipality?
A: Unless specified by contract, the municipality is responsible for all costs associated with the transfer of the electronically stored data to the municipality. This process should be included in the contract and/or work plan for every assessor.

Q: Who owns the assessment data?
A: The municipality owns the assessment data regardless of the contract's terms or software license.

Q: When the  municipality hires a new assessor, when does the outgoing assessor need to transfer  the data to the municipality?
A: The outgoing assessor must provide all the assessment data to the municipal  clerk within 30 days of vacating the Assessor's office or must provide it at  the Board of Review's (BOR) final adjournment, whichever is later.

Q: What assessment data does an outgoing assessor need to provide to the municipality?
A:
The outgoing assessor must provide the municipality with all assessment records (paper and electronic) in the assessor's custody. Even though an assessor must maintain electronic assessment data, the assessor must also provide the municipality with a paper copy of each property record card if requested. If paper records are converted to an electronic format, the assessor must return the original paper records to the municipality.
If the outgoing assessor used a proprietary assessment system, the outgoing assessor must provide the data to the municipality in two formats:
- The format native to the customized or uncommon software
- A non-proprietary format (comma delimited text, MS-Access, DB2, SQL, XML). Definitions for all fields must be provided. See Assessment and Tax Roll Electronic File Transmissions for assessment software vendors that can generate parcel data XML files and comply with DOR's XML parcel data standard.

Q: What commercial data must be maintained electronically?
A: The minimum commercial data is the information identified on the residential Property Record Card ( PA-500 ), including all data applied to determine the assessment.

Q: What mobile home data must be maintained electronically?
A: The minimum mobile home data must identify whether the mobile home is real propertyor subject to a parking permit fee, and must include the data used to determine the assessment.

Q: What happens if an assessor does not comply with the electronic assessment data requirement or fails to provide DOR with the required electronic assessment data?
A: Failure to comply results in DOR reviewing the assessor's certification and could result in suspension or revocation of the certification.

Q: After all my property records are in an electronic format, do I still need to maintain a paper copy?
A:
If you can produce a paper copy of the current  Property Record Card ( PA-500 ) when requested, you are not required to update the paper copy. However, annually at the close of the BOR, you must produce a paper copy of the Property Record Card for each parcel before making any changes for the coming year.
Note: Municipalities are required by the State Public Records Board and state law to retain Property Record Cards for seven years.

Q: What is the maximum amount a town, village, city or county can levy?
A:
Towns, villages, cities and counties use the Levy Limit Worksheet to determine the maximum allowable property tax levy they can implement without potentially receiving a penalty under state law (sec. 66.0602 , Wis. Stats.).
On the Levy Limit Worksheet (Forms SL-202M and SL-202C)
- Your allowable levy is the amount in Section A, Line 10
- Line 10 is the sum of Line 8 (levy limit before adjustments less personal property aid) and Line 9 (total adjustments from Section D)
Special resolution (Form SL-202M)
- If a town with a population less than 3,000 approves a levy limit increase by special resolution, it must enter the total town tax levy (including the increase approved by the town electors) in Section A, Line 11
- The amount on Line 11 is your allowable levy

Q: Where do I report the actual levy on the Levy Limit Worksheet?
A:
Your actual levy is not reported on the Levy Limit Worksheet. Municipalities should report their actual levy on the Statement of Taxes (SOT). Counties report their actual levy on the State and County Apportionment form (SCTA).
The Levy Limit Worksheet is used to calculate and report the allowable levy limit. Even if your actual levy is less than your allowable levy limit, you must submit your Levy Limit Worksheet showing your allowable levy limit. Your actual levy is reported on your SOT or SCTA.

Q: Do I need to complete the Levy Limit Worksheet if there are no adjustments to our allowable levy?
A: Yes. Each county and municipality must submit a Levy Limit Worksheet to the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) by December 15 of each year. You should review your allowable levy limit before adjustments, shown in Section A, Line 8, to ensure your municipality's or county's property tax levy is less than or equal to the allowable levy limit. If there are no adjustments, you would enter $0 on all adjustment lines in Section D, and submit the auto-filled worksheet to DOR.

Q: What is our allowable levy limit?
A:
Use the Levy Limit Worksheet to calculate your maximum allowable levy for the current year. The starting number in this calculation is the previous year's actual levy from the Statement of Taxes for municipalities or the State and County Apportionment Form for counties (except if there was an excess levy in the previous year) plus the current year's personal property aid payment for code 2 and Act 12 personal property aid. The allowable adjustments from Section D of the Levy Limit Worksheet varies by municipality and county. The total adjustments reported in Section D of the Levy Limit Worksheet auto-fills inSection A, Line 9and is added to Section A Line 8 to arrive at the total allowable levy in Section A, Line 10.
Complete the appropriate Levy Limit Worksheet:
- County Levy Limit Worksheet (Form SL-202C)
- Municipal Levy Limit Worksheet (Form SL-202M)

Q: What impact does personal property aid have on levy limits?
A:
Per Wis. Act 59, Code 2 personal property  locally assessed machinery, tools and patterns, can no longer be levied. Instead, the Wisconsin Department of Revenue will distribute a personal property aid payment under sec. 79.096, Wis. Stats. Effective for December 2018 tax levies, the allowable levy limit is reduced by this personal property aid. The reduction in the levy limit is replaced by the personal property aid payment issued the first Monday in May each year, beginning in May 2019.
In addition to Wis. Act 59 , per Wis. Act 12, all personal property is exempt and can no longer be levied for. Instead, the Wisconsin Department of Revenue will distribute a new personal property aid payment under sec. 79.0965, Wis. Stats. Effective for December 2024 tax levies, the allowable levy limit is reduced by this new personal property aid. The reduction in the levy limit is replaced by the personal property aid payment issued the first Monday in May each year, beginning in May 2025.

Q: What is "net new construction?"
A:
- DOR's Equalization Bureau calculates net new construction each year
- It includes changes to equalized value due to new building construction and land improvements minus changes to equalized value due to the demolition/destruction of buildings and removal of land improvements
- Net new construction amounts for each county and municipality is located at: revenue.wi.gov/Pages/EQU/nnc.aspx

Q: Does net new construction include or exclude property in tax incremental financing (TIF) districts?
A: Net new construction is calculated based on all taxable property in a municipality or county, including property in TIFs.

Q: How does the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) use net new construction?
A:
DOR uses net new construction as part of the county and municipal levy limits.
Note: The percentage used on the Levy Limit Worksheet is carried out to three decimal places, the Net New Construction Report only shows two decimal places.

Q: Does DOR use net new construction for other calculations?
A:
Yes. DOR uses net new construction to determine the allowable increase in spending under the Expenditure Restraint Incentive Program (ERIP).
For ERIP worksheet purposes, the allowable budget percentage change increase is calculated as follows: 60% of net new construction plus Consumer Price Index (CPI), not to exceed CPI plus 2%.
Note: The percentage used to calculate the allowable increase in spending under the ERIP is carried out to three decimal places, the Net New Construction Report only shows two decimal places.

Q: When is net new construction available?
A: DOR posts the Net New Construction Report to our website by August 15 each year.

Q: What is Act 12 personal property aid?
A: Beginning in 2024, per 2023 Wisconsin Act 12, personal property is tax exempt. Exceptions: Property assessed as real property under s. 70.17(3), Property subject to taxation under s. 76.025(2).Act 12 personal property aid is equal to the property tax amount previously levied on personal property items

Q: How is Act 12 personal property aid calculated?
A:
- The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) calculates the payment based on the January 1, 2023, personal property value
- Under state law (sec. 79.0965 , Wis. Stats.), Act 12 personal property aid is equal to the amount of property taxes levied on items of personal property

Q: How does the Act 12 personal property aid payment affect the district's Levy Limit Worksheet?
A:
- The levy limit is the prior year actual levy plus the personal property aid payment (Code 2 and Act 12 personal property) multiplied by the valuation factor, minus the Code 2 and Act 12 personal property aid payment for the municipality or county only plus/minus adjustments from Section D of the levy limit worksheet. It does not include the additional Code 2 and Act 12 personal property aid paid to a municipality or county for the termination of a tax incremental district.
- Valuation factor means a percentage equal to the greater of either:
- Percentage change in the political subdivision's January 1 equalized value due to new construction, less improvements removed between the previous year and the current
- Zero percent

Q: When do taxation districts receive the Act 12 personal property aid payment?
A: DOR distributes Act 12 personal property aid on the first Monday in May.

Q: What is personal property aid?
A:
- Beginning in 2018, per 2017 Wisconsin Act 59 , locally assessed Code 2 personal property (machinery, tools and patterns) is tax exempt
- Personal property aid is equal to the property tax amount previously levied on locally assessed Code 2 personal property items

Q: Who qualifies for personal property aid?
A:
- Each active county, municipality, school district, technical college district, special district, and tax incremental financing district (TID) with Code 2 personal property as of January 1, 2017, is eligible to receive an aid payment
- Exceptions: Dissolved districts (other than TIDs) do not receive a payment Due to a law change, effective for 2022 personal property aid payments and forward, when a TID terminates, the year following the termination, the personal property aid payment is now distributed to all taxing jurisdictions within the TID
- Dissolved districts (other than TIDs) do not receive a payment
- Due to a law change, effective for 2022 personal property aid payments and forward, when a TID terminates, the year following the termination, the personal property aid payment is now distributed to all taxing jurisdictions within the TID

Q: How is personal property aid calculated?
A:
- The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) calculates the payment based on the January 1, 2017 locally assessed value of Code 2 personal property
- Under state law (sec. 79.096, Wis. Stats.), personal property aid is equal to the amount of property taxes levied on items of locally assessed Code 2 personal property

Q: How does the personal property aid payment affect the district's Levy Limit Worksheet?
A:
- The levy limit is the prior year actual levy multiplied by the valuation factor, minus the personal property aid payment for the municipality or county only. It does not include the additional personal property aid paid to a municipality or county for the termination of a tax incremental  district.
- Valuation factor means a percentage equal to the greater of either: Percentage change in the political subdivision's January 1 equalized value due to new construction, less improvements removed between the previous year and the current Zero percent
- Percentage change in the political subdivision's January 1 equalized value due to new construction, less improvements removed between the previous year and the current
- Zero percent

Q: When do taxation districts receive the personal property aid payment?
A: DOR distributes personal property aid on the first Monday in May.

Q: What is the Statement of Assessment (SOA)?
A:
A municipal clerk or real property lister electronically files (e-files) the SOA with the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR). Once the Board of Review (BOR) adjourns and adjustments are made on the assessment roll, the clerk or real property lister reports the locally assessed values to DOR. The SOA is an official listing of the statutory classification and assessed values of all properties within a given municipality (town, village, city), which include:
- Number of land and improved parcel counts for the different classes of real estate
- Number of acres for the different classes of real estate
- Private Forest Crop and/or Managed Forest Land parcels, acres and assessed values
- Special district  assessed values
- School and technical college assessed values
- Up to two prior years of omitted values
- Prior year corrections of errors by assessors
It is important that the values are accurate and reported timely since the values are used to:
- Certify school, technical college and special district equalized values
- Create a Final SOA used to calculate property tax bills
- Determine the ratio for calculating fair market value estimates used on the property tax bills
- Note: Final SOAs are posted on our Reports web page from October through December

Q: What is the deadline to file an SOA?
A:
- Second Monday in June, or
- After your BOR is complete  do not file your SOA until the BOR adjourns and all adjustments are made to the assessment roll

Q: How do I submit the SOA?
A:
You must electronically file (e-file) the SOA with DOR. There are two methods available to e-file this form.
- File transfer  you may use this method if your county has an approved file format Visit the Government E-Services File Transfer page Select "Ready to Transfer" under "Statement of Assessment File Transmission" Submit your file Save your receipt number If there is an issue with your file, we will contact you
- Visit the Government E-Services File Transfer page
- Select "Ready to Transfer" under "Statement of Assessment File Transmission"
- Submit your file
- Save your receipt number
- If there is an issue with your file, we will contact you
- E-file form  you may e-file this form Visit the Government E-Services Online Filing page Select the "Statement of Assessment" (PA-521C) Enter the required information and submit to DOR Print and/or save a copy for your records, including your confirmation number For more information, review Online Filing Help  Using My DOR Government Account
- Visit the Government E-Services Online Filing page
- Select the "Statement of Assessment" (PA-521C)
- Enter the required information and submit to DOR
- Print and/or save a copy for your records, including your confirmation number
- For more information, review Online Filing Help  Using My DOR Government Account

Q: Do I need a PIN number or password to use the File Transfer method?
A: No. You are not required to use a PIN number or password, or pre-register.

Q: Do I need a PIN number or password to use the E-file form?
A: Since the form is located in My DOR Government Account (MyDORGov), you must be an authorized MyDORGov user. For more information, review Online Filing Help  Using My DOR Government Account .

Q: Why is it important to submit a complete and accurate SOA?
A:
DOR uses data from the SOA to:
- Certify school, technical college and special district equalized values
- Create a Final SOA used to calculate property tax bills
- Determine the ratio for calculating fair market value estimates used on the property tax bills

Q: Why did the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) contact us about our Managed Forest Land (MFL) or Private Forest Crop (PFC) acreage?
A: In March each year, the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources (DNR) provides DOR with a file listing the MFL and PFC acres in each municipality. If DOR contacted you, it may be because the acreage you submitted on the SOA did not reflect the acreage provided by DNR, and you did not provide an explanation as to why the acreage did not match.

Q: How often do Managed Forest (MFL) rates change and how are we notified
A: Rates can change every five years. The last rate update occurred in 2023; prior rates changed in 2018. The next rate update will be in 2028. DOR updates the form and instructions, emails municipalities with the new rates, and discusses the changes in training opportunities.

Q: Do I need to report an assessed value for a special district if it does not levy any tax?
A: Yes. Since DOR is required to certify equalized values of legally formed town sanitary districts, public lake protection and rehab districts, and metropolitan sewer districts, the assessed value must be reported.

Q: Where do I report our correction of errors by assessors values on the SOA?
A: Report sec. 70.43, corrections of errors on Line 23, Column C1 for real estate and Line 23, Column C2 for personal property. These values should be for prior years. If the correction of errors is reducing a value, the value you report will be a negative value. If you report a sec. 70.43 correction on the SOA, you must report the corresponding amount of net taxes or refund due in Sec. I of the SOT.

Q: Where do I report our omitted values on the SOA?
A: Report sec. 70.44, omitted property from prior years, on Line 23, Column A for real estate and Line 23, Column B for personal property. If you report a sec. 70.44 omitted property value on the SOA, you must report the corresponding amount of net taxes due in Section H of the SOT.

Q: Where can I find my final SOA?
A:
DOR posts Final SOAs October through December each year. As we complete an SOA, DOR posts each final SOA (which includes manufacturing values) on our website at: revenue.wi.gov/Pages/Report/Home.aspx .
Note: Once a final SOA is posted to our website, DOR will not equate and post another SOA.

Q: I filed my SOA. Why isn't there a final SOA for  my municipality?
A: DOR works on final SOAs in batches starting in mid-late October through December and posts Final SOAs after we complete each batch.

Q: I amended my SOA. Why don't I see the amended  values on the final SOA?
A: Since other processes rely on an SOA's information, it is important for DOR to have the most accurate SOA. If you amended your SOA after we posted the final to our website, we will still process it. However, we will not post the Final SOA with the amended values. DOR will not calculate a new aggregate ratio. When you compile property tax bills, use the aggregate ratio found on the Final SOA and the updated values from the amended SOA.

Q: Are there additional resources for the SOA process?
A: Yes. Review Publication PA-502 , Assessment and Tax Roll Instructions for Clerks. This publication provides an overview of the SOA and other processes a clerk and/or treasurer may be responsible for throughout the year.

Q: After the BOR has adjourned, can I amend my SOA by adding a parcel or improvement not applied to the current tax roll?
A: No. This would be considered omitted property. According to state law (sec. 70.44, Wis. Stats.) and Chapter 7 of the Wisconsin Property Assessment Manual, any property discovered omitted from the currently year after the BOR adjourns will be assessed and taxed in the next year as omitted. Report omitted property on Line 23 A (real estate) and Line 23 B (personal property) on the next year's SOA.

Q: Can I amend my SOA correcting a palpable error discovered after the BOR already adjourned? (sec. 74.33, Wis. Stats.)
A: Under state law (sec. 70.73 (1m), Wis. Stats.), after the BOR adjourns, if a palpable error (sec. 74.33(1)) is discovered in the assessment roll, the clerk or treasurer must correct the assessment roll before calculating the property taxes and then notify the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) of the correction under sec. 70.57, Wis. Stats.

Q: What is the Records Disposition Authorization (RDA) for the Statement of Assessment (Form PA-521C)?
A: The SOA's RDA is the date the form was submitted to DOR plus seven years.

Q: What is an SOT?
A:
The SOT is a form the municipality electronically files (e-files) with the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) after the tax roll is completed. After submitting the SOT, the municipality sends a copy to the county treasurer and keep a copy for the district's records. - Summarizes all taxes and charges placed on the tax roll for collection
- Enables a clerk to uniformly report the taxation district taxes and charges to DOR

Q: What is the deadline to file an SOT?
A: You must file the SOT with DOR by the third Monday in December.

Q: How do I file an SOT?
A:
- E-file form - located at: revenue.wi.gov/Pages/OnlineServices/slfiling.aspx
- Note: After filing, send a copy to the county treasurer and keep a copy for the districts records

Q: Why is it important to submit a complete and accurate SOT?
A:
- All adjustments are made to the tax roll
- Total tax roll amount is known, including any overrun or underrun
- Tax roll is complete, summarized, and returned to the clerk
- Tax Increment Worksheet is completed (if applicable)

Q: Why did the Wisconsin Department of Revenue contact us about our Managed Forest Land (MFL) or Private Forest Crop (PFC) acreage?
A: If DOR contacted your municipality, it may be because the acreage you reported on the SOT did not match the acreage you reported on the Statement of Assessment (SOA), and you did not provide an explanation as to why acreage did not agree.

Q: How do I report our chargeback on the SOT?
A: If you reported a sec. 70.43 corrections of errors on Line 23 of the SOA, report the corresponding amount of net taxes or refund due in Section I of the SOT. If you refunded or rescinded taxes, your correction will be a negative value.

Q: How do I report our omitted property on the SOT?
A: If you reported a sec. 70.44, omitted property from prior years on Line 23 of the SOA, report the corresponding amount of net taxes due in Section H of the SOT.

Q: How do I amend our SOT?
A: You must submit an amended SOT on our website at revenue.wi.gov/Pages/OnlineServices/slfiling.aspx. Note: The "Amended" box is automatically checked.

Q: Are there additional resources for the SOT process?
A: Yes. Review Assessment and Tax Roll Instructions for Clerks (PA-502). This publication provides an overview of the SOT and other processes a clerk and/or treasurer may be responsible for throughout the year.

Q: Who should file the tax exempt property data and by when?
A: In even years, the property owner (or representative) must file the Tax Exemption Report (Form PC220) for single parcels or Form PC220A for multiple parcels, with the Municipal Clerk no later than March 31. (sec. 70.337, Wis. Stats.)

Q: What does themunicipal clerk do with the data?
A: The clerk compiles the data and enters it on the Taxation District Exemption Summary Report (Form PC-226) .

Q: Which property types require a report?
A:
Must file a report for: (sec. 70.11 , Wis. Stats.)
- Church/Religious - place of Worship (sec. 70.11(4), Wis. Stats.)
- Other Church/Religious (sec. 70.11, Wis. Stats.)
- Private Educational Schools (sec. 70.11(4), Wis. Stats.)
- Private Colleges (sec. 70.11(3), Wis. Stats.)
- Other Education (sec. 70.11, Wis. Stats.)
- Medical facility - (includes religious), Non-Profit Hospital (sec. 70.11(4m), Wis. Stats.)
- Medical Research Foundation (sec. 70.11(25), Wis. Stats.)
- Other Medical Facility (sec. 70.11, Wis. Stats.)
- Housing - (includes religious), Nursing Home (sec. 70.11(4),(19), Wis. Stats.)
- Retirement Home (sec. 70.11(3a),(4), Wis. Stats.)
- Other Housing (sec. 70.11(3a),(18),(19), Wis. Stats.)
- Public Benefit - YMCA/YWCA, Scouts, Boys' Club, Youth Hockey (sec. 70.11(12),(32), Wis. Stats.)
- Lions Camp, Bible Camp, Camp for Handicapped (sec. 70.11(10m),(11),(22), Wis. Stats.)
- Women's Club, Historical Society, Library Assoc. (sec. 70.11(4),(31m), Wis. Stats.)
- Fraternal, Labor/Farmers' Temple, Agri Fair (sec. 70.11(4),(5),(16),(17), Wis. Stats.)
- Nonprofit Radio, theatre, Art Gallery (sec. 70.11(14),(29),(29m), Wis. Stats.)
- Sports and Entertainment Facility/Stadium (sec. 70.11(31)(36), Wis. Stats.)
- Humane Society (sec. 70.11(28), Wis. Stats.)
- Historical Site, Public Trust (sec. 70.11(9),(20),(34),(35), Wis. Stats.)
- All other (sec. 70.11, Wis. Stats.)
Do not have to file a report for: (sec. 70.11 , Wis. Stats.)
- Property owned by the Federal, State, County and Municipal Governments including State and county forests
- Cemeteries, exempt under sec. 70.11(13), Wis. Stats.
- Archeological sites, exempt under sec. 70.11(13m), Wis. Stats.
- Manure storage facilities, exempt under sec. 70.11(15), Wis. Stats.
- Secondary containment structures used to prevent leakage of liquid fertilizer or pesticides, exempt under sec. 70.11(15m), Wis. Stats.
- Treatment plant and pollution abatement equipment, exempt under sec. 70.11(21), Wis. Stats.
- All perennial plants that produce an annual crop, exempt under sec. 70.77(30), Wis. Stats.
- Property of housing authorities exempt under sec. 70.11(18), Wis. Stats., if a payment in lieu of taxes is made for that property
- Lake beds owned by the State
- Highways, as defined in sec. 340.01(22), Wis. Stats.
- Utility property assessed under Chapter 76
- Public School and Public Technical college districts

Q: What if a property owner doesn't file a Tax Exempt Report (Form PC-220) with their municipal clerk or the assessor doesn't know the property's value?
A:
Tax exemption report filing details (sec. 70.337, Wis. Stats.):
- Property owner files property tax exemption request (Form PR-230) with assessor by March 1 each year
- Property owner files Form PC-220 with their municipal clerk by March 31 of each even-numbered year, under sec. 70.337, Wis. Stats.
- Clerk uses the PC-220 form information to complete the Taxation District Exemption Summary Report (Form PC-226) located in MyDORGov
- If the municipal clerk does not receive the PC-220 form by March 31 of the even-numbered year, the clerk will send the property owner a notice by certified mail stating the property will be appraised at the owners expense within 30 days of the date the notice is sent. Either the assessor or person hired by the assessor will conduct the appraisal. (sec. 70.337(6), Wis. Stats.)

Q: What is the Tax Increment Worksheet (TIW)?
A: The Tax Increment Worksheet ( PC-202 ) calculates property tax amounts for the Tax Incremental Districts (TIDs) within a municipality. The TIW uses the overlying taxing jurisdiction's apportioned tax levies and the value increment within each taxing jurisdiction to determine their share of the tax increment. The total tax increment is distributed to the municipality's TIDs.

Q: Who needs to file the TIW?
A:
Any town, village or city with one or more TIDs with a positive total value increment must complete the TIW each year. You must file this worksheet before you can file the Statement of Taxes (SOT).
Note: If your TID has a negative total value increment, you are not required to submit a TIW; however, you must still file an SOT.

Q: How do I file the TIW?
A: You must electronically file the TIW. This form is located in My DOR Government Account . For more information, review our Online Filing Help  Using My DOR Government Account .

Q: What is the deadline to file the TIW?
A: Each required municipality must e-file the TIW with the Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) by the third Monday in December. Note: You must file the TIW before you complete the mill rate worksheet.

Q: Where do my values come from for filing the TIW?
A:
Most values on the TIW are auto-filled. The only value you need to report is the municipality's local levy, which is the sum of these lines from the Statement of Taxes (SOT):
- Other special purpose district taxes ( Line C1)
- Other state special charges (Line C4)
- County special charges (Line C5)
- All other town, village or city taxes (Line C6)
Note:
- Do not include any tax increment in your municipality's local levy
- Special purpose districts are not authorizedtaxing jurisdictions; in result, you must include their levies in your municipality's local levy on the TIW

Q: What if an auto-filled apportioned levy is missing or incorrect?
A: You must contact the taxing jurisdiction directly and notify DOR's Local Government Services Bureau. Taxing jurisdictions (except schools) report their apportioned levies to DOR. School districts provide their apportioned levies to the Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction (DPI), which is shared with DOR.

Q: Which levy amount from the TIW should I use to calculate property tax mill rates  Column A (Apportioned Levy) or Column E (Levy Amount)?
A: Use Column E (Levy Amount) to calculate mill rates for property tax bills. This will ensure the total apportioned tax levies and the tax increment are collected. Column A (Apportioned Levy) amounts will be shown on your municipality's SOT. Column F's (Tax Increment) amount will appear on the SOT, Section C, Line 2.

Q: I found an error on my TIW; can I fix it?
A: Yes. You can electronically amend Form PC-202 to correct your municipal levy entry, located on our website: https://www.revenue.wi.gov/Pages/OnlineServices/slfiling.aspx After you amend the TIW, you must also amend the SOT.

Q: What happens if I use the wrong levy from the TIW in my mill rate calculations?
A: Always use TIW, Column E levies for your mill rate calculations.  If you use the apportioned levies (Column A), you will not collect the tax increment for your TIF districts and may need to reissue propertytax bills.

Q: Do I need to provide a copy of the TIW to the county?
A: You must provide your completed Tax Increment Worksheet to the county if the county is printing your tax bills.

Q: What is the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet?
A: The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) provides the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet( Form PC-501 ) for counties to report the February settlements. DOR uses the completed form to verify tax collections compared to the taxes levied in the municipal records. DOR also uses the formto identify and resolve discrepancies. The Treasurer's Settlement Sheet should reconcile with the Statement of Taxes ( SOT ).

Q: Am I required to file a Treasurer's Settlement Sheet?
A:
- February settlements - Yes. Under state law (sec. 74.25, Wis. Stats.), counties must submit a Treasurer's Settlement Sheet for municipalities with February settlements to DOR by March 15.
- August settlements - under state law (sec. 74.30, Wis. Stats.), if you have an August settlement, submitting a Treasurer's Settlement Sheet is optional

Q: What is the deadline for filing the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet?
A:
- March  15 - if your municipality has a February Settlement, DOR must receive the completed form by March 15
- Note: Also provide a copy to the municipal clerk and treasurer, and the county treasurer

Q: How do I submit the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet?
A:
You must electronically file (e-file) the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet with DOR. There are two methods available to e-file this form:
- File transfer - you may use this method if your  county has an approved  file format Visit the Government  E-Services File Transfer page Select "Ready to  Transfer" under "Treasurer's Settlement Sheet File Transmission" Submit your file Save your receipt number If there is a problem with  your file, we will contact you
- Visit the Government  E-Services File Transfer page
- Select "Ready to  Transfer" under "Treasurer's Settlement Sheet File Transmission"
- Submit your file
- Save your receipt number
- If there is a problem with  your file, we will contact you
- E-file form - you may e-file this form. Many fields automatically calculate and/or pre-fill based on values reported to DOR on other forms (ex: SOT, Apportionments) Visit the Government  E-Services Online Filing page Select the "Treasurer's Settlement Sheet" (PC-501) Enter the required information and submit to DOR Print and/or save a copy for your records, including your confirmation number
- Visit the Government  E-Services Online Filing page
- Select the "Treasurer's Settlement Sheet" (PC-501)
- Enter the required information and submit to DOR
- Print and/or save a copy for your records, including your confirmation number

Q: Do I need a PIN number or password to use the File Transfer method?
A: No. You are not required to use a PIN number or password, or pre-register.

Q: Do I need a PIN number or password to use the E-file form?
A: This form is located in My DOR Government Account . You must be authorized to file. For more information, review our Online Filing Help  Using My DOR Government Account .

Q: Will my data be encrypted or otherwise protected when it's transmitted over the Internet?
A: Yes. Your data is protected during transmission. The file posts through HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol over SSL) to a web server and the data is protected with SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) 128-bit encryption. This encrypted protocol is the same standard used for Internet financial transactions.

Q: Will I receive a confirmation receipt after I submit the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet?
A:
File transfer method
- Successful transfer - Yes. If the file transferred successfully, you will receive a notification ("OK Transfer Complete") that DOR accepted the file. If there are errors or we cannot process the file, we will contact you.
- Unsuccessful transfer - if your file did not transfer, you will receive a notification stating that errors exist and must be corrected before submitting
E-file form - after submitting a complete and error-free form, you will see a date stamp and confirmation number. Save and/or print the form for your records.

Q: What information do I need to file the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet?
A:
You need a complete tax roll, where:
- All collections and state tax credits have been applied
- First dollar and lottery and gaming credits have been posted
- All unpaid taxes were extended
- Tax roll is balanced and reconciled to the Certificate of Correctness and SOT
For more detailed information, review " Instructions - Tax District Treasurer's Settlement Sheet ."

Q: What if the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet and the Statement of Taxes (SOT) do not reconcile?
A:
The Treasurer's Settlement Sheet and the SOT should reconcile. If they do not, you must:
- Notify the municipality
- Provide DOR with a detailed explanation why the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet does not reflect what is reported on the SOT
- If the discrepancy is due to incorrect information on the SOT, amend the SOT to correct any identified errors

Q: How often do Managed Forest (MFL) rates change and how are we notified?
A: Rates can change every five years. The last rate update occurred in 2023; prior rates change in 2018. The next rate update will be 2028. DOR updates the form and instructions, emails municipalities with the new rates, and discusses the changes in training opportunities.

Q: Can I amend the Treasurer's Settlement Sheet?
A:
Yes. You may amend the Treasurer's Settlement by using either the file transfer or e-file method. If a municipality has a duplicate file transfer, DOR recognizes it as amended.
Note: When using the e-file form, the report type will show "Amended," complete all required information and submit. Print and/or save the amended copy for your records.

Q: Why aren't personal property roll taxes reported on the Treasurer's Settlement?
A: Starting January 1, 2024, all locally assessed and manufacturing personal property became exempt under 2023 Wisconsin Act 12 . The exempt personal property is now an aid payment your municipality receives the first Monday, each May.

Q: What is industrial waste?
A:
- Any gas, liquid or solid matter resulting from a process of industry, manufacture, trade, business or the development of any natural resource
- Industrial waste has no monetary value and would otherwise be considered superfluous or discarded material
- Industrial waste can be used to produce heat or steam for a manufacturing process if the fuel consists of one of the following: 95 percentor more industrial waste that would otherwise be superfluous or discarded material 50 percentor more of wood chips, sawdust, or other wood residue from the paper and wood products manufacturing process, if the wood chips, sawdust, or other wood residue would otherwise be superfluous or discarded
- 95 percentor more industrial waste that would otherwise be superfluous or discarded material
- 50 percentor more of wood chips, sawdust, or other wood residue from the paper and wood products manufacturing process, if the wood chips, sawdust, or other wood residue would otherwise be superfluous or discarded

Q: What are air contaminants?
A:
- Air contaminants include : dust, fumes, mist, liquid, smoke, other particulate matter, vapor, gas, odorous substances or a combination of  the above
- Air contaminants do not include : uncombined water vapor (sec. 285.01(1), Wis. Stats.)

Q: What property qualifies for this exemption?
A:
- Dust collection systems
- Air cleaners
- Electrostatic precipitators
- Equipment used to remove smoke or fumes from welders
- Scrubbers used to remove air pollutants
- Wastewater pretreatment systems
- Waste holding tanks
- Wood waste burning process boilers
- Aerators
- Ridge and furrow systems and industrial wastewater holding ponds
- Thermal incinerators
- Gas vapor recovery equipment at gas stations
- Paint booths
- Makeup air units replacing air removed from the interior of a building by other equipment or processes with air from outside of the building
- Equipment used to compact or bale waste to reduce volume
- Storage tanks used outside of production process
- Equipment used for sewage treatment or garbage handling
- Conversion of a furnace from one type of fuel to another type of fuel
- Equipment treating uncombined water vapor (ex: steam)
- Unnecessary siltation resulting from operations, including washing of vegetables or raw food products, gravel washing, stripping of lands for development of subdivisions, highways, quarries and gravel pits, mine drainage, cleaning of vehicles or barges, or gross neglect of land erosion
- Smokestacks with increased height to diffuse emissions over a wider area
- Monitoring equipment that is not a component or integral part of a waste treatment facility
- Equipment used to remove trimmings or scraps from the production process when those items have monetary value
- Land used to dispose industrial waste and also used to grow agricultural products that are sold

Q: If I sell the crop grown on my agricultural land where a food processor or manufacturer spreads wastewater, does the land qualify for the waste treatment exemption?
A:
- Cuts the cover crop and lets it lie in the field
- Leases property to a farmer; the farmer plants, harvests and feeds the crop to his own cattle
- Grows the crop and allows an area farmer to harvest and feed the crop to the farmer's cattle
- Allows an area farmer, at no charge, to grow, harvest and feed the crop to the farmer's cattle
- Leases property to a farmer; the farmer plants, harvests and sells the cover crop
- Grows, harvests and uses the crop in his/her own manufacturing process (ex: canning company)
- Harvests the crop and sells it
- Sells the crop instead of feeding it to his cattle

Q: Where can I find more information on this exemption?
A:
- General property taxes ch. 70
- Treatment plant and pollution abatement equipment ch. 70.11(21)
- State assessment of manufacturing property ch.70.995
- Air pollution definitions ch. 285.01
- Industrial waste definitions ch. 289

Q: How do I know if a Tax Incremental District (TID) is affected by2023 Act 12?
A: Review the TID's creation and territory amendment documents to identify whether the TID's base value includes personal property accounts. If the base value includes personal property, review with the assessor to determine whether the personal property is exempted by 2023 Act 12.

Q: How should a municipality submit an adjustment request?
A:
Complete the Personal Property Removal Workbook and email it to tif@wisconsin.gov.
- List all personal property included in the TID's base value that is tax exempt as of January 1, 2024
- Do not include personal property assessed as real estate (ex: buildings on leased land)
- If you are unsure whether personal property in the TID's base value is tax exempt in 2024, review with your municipal assessor

Q: Why should a municipality submit an adjustment request?
A: Personal property exempted under 2023 Act 12 will be removed from the TID's current year value beginning in 2024. Adjusting the TID's base value by removing the exempt personal property allows for the correct increment calculation. Starting in 2024, the TID's assessed value does not include personal property.

Q: What is the deadline to submit an adjustment request?
A:
October 31 each year is the deadline to submit a request for the following tax year.
DOR will review requests received:
- By October 31, 2024 for adjustment in the 2025 tax year
- Between November 1, 2024 and October 31, 2025 for adjustment in the 2026 tax year

Q: There was no personal property assessed in the TID for 2023. Does this mean there was no personal property included in the base value? Does the municipality still need to submit an adjustment request?
A: Personal property included in the TID's base value may be different than the personal property currently assessed in the TID. Review the TID's creation and territory amendment documents to identify if the TID's base value includes personal property. You only need to submit an adjustment request if personal property was included in the TID's base value and it is exempt starting in 2024.

Q: How does a TID personal property base value adjustment affect the TID's increment?
A:
- A TID's current value minus the base value equals the value increment
- Before January 1, 2024, taxable personal property assessed in the TID was included in the TID's current value and contributed to a TID's tax increment
- Removing exempt personal property from the base value ensures both the TID's base value and current value exclude exempt personal property value

Q: Does the municipality have to submit a Personal Property Removal Workbook every year?
A: No, submit one Personal Property Removal Workbook for each TID that includes personal property in the base. If your municipality already submitted a request, you do not need to resubmit.

Q: How do we complete the Personal Property Removal Workbook if the base value documents do not include all the information requested on the workbook, such as account numbers or addresses?
A: When completing the "PP  Base Values" worksheet in the Personal Property Removal Workbook , provide the available information from the TID's creation and territory amendment documents. If specific information is not available on creation or territory amendment documents, leave those columns blank. DOR must be able to match the accounts on the "PP  Base Values" worksheet to the TID's creation and territory amendment documents.

Q: A municipality created a TID in 2023. The 2023 values include personal property that will be exempt due to 2023 Act 12. Do we still need to submit an adjustment request or will DOR adjust these TIDs automatically?
A: Since 2023 Act 12 is effective on January 1, 2024, DOR must include personal property values when establishing the base value for TIDs created in 2023. A municipality must complete and submit the Personal Property Adjustment Request for 2023 TID creations that include personal property exempt under 2023 Act 12.

Q: Does completing the adjustment request affect the amount of personal property aid the TID receives?
A: No, a TID's personal property aid is determined by its 2023 personal property value. The TID personal property adjustment request only affects the TID's base value.

Q: Is a TID created in 2023 eligible for personal property aid?
A: No, the aid applies to TIDs on the 2023 tax/assessment roll. A TID created in 2023 will be added to the tax/assessment roll in 2024. See TID Creation Timeframes .

Q: What is an allocation amendment?
A: An allocation amendment allows a TID with excess funds (the donor) to transfer funds to another TID (the recipient).

Q: Which TID type can allocate to another?
A: See the TID Allocation Amendment Types .

Q: Can a  municipality allocate increment between its Tax Incremental Districts (TIDs) with different overlying  taxing jurisdictions?
A: No. State law (sec. 66.1105(6)(f)1.a , Wis. Stats.) requires that both Donor and Recipient TIDs have the same overlying taxing jurisdictions.

Q: Which TID project plan should a municipality amend to allocate increment from one TID to another, the Donor TID or Recipient TID?
A: A municipality must amend the Donor TID's project plan. For details on how to complete an allocation amendment, see Municipal TIF Project Plan and/or Allocation Amendments .

Q: If a municipality amends both TID 1 and TID 2 to share increment with TID 3, how many updated project plans are needed?
A: If the municipality is amending TID 1 and TID 2 to become Donor TIDs, it must update the project plan for each TID. The economic feasibility section of each project plan must show that the Donor TID has extra increment to share.

Q: Does the public hearing notice for an allocation amendment need to include the amount of the donation?
A: Yes, the public hearing notice must include the estimated donation amount. The notice for any TID amendment must include the purpose and cost of the amendment. For assistance, see the sample notices on the TIF Public Notices web page.

Q: After a municipality completes an allocation amendment, can the municipality decide not to allocate the funds?
A: Yes. The municipality can (for whatever reason) choose not to allocate after completing the allocation amendment. There is no additional action required if this occurs.

Q: If a Donor TID paid all its project costs, can it stay open solely to allocate to another TID?
A: Yes. If the Donor TID has not reached its maximum life, after the Donor TID's allocation amendment resolution is approved, it can stay open to allocate funds to another TID.

Q: After a TID becomes a donor, can the municipality amend the donor TID's project plan to add new project costs?
A:
Yes. The municipality can amend its project plan to add new project costs if the donor TID has not reached the end of its expenditure period.
After the donor TID's expenditure period ends, the municipality can continue to donate funds but cannot amend the plan to add new project costs.

Q: When can an allocation transfer take place?
A:
If funds are available from the Donor TID, the allocation transfer can occur after the municipal resolution is adopted and the JRB approves the allocation amendment.
After the JRB approves the amendment, the municipality can transfer funds according to the project plan without requesting JRB approval for each transfer.

Q: Can allocations be made after the expenditure period?
A: Yes. After the Donor TID's expenditure period ends, the municipality can allocate funds until the Donor TID reaches its maximum life.

Q: Can a municipality amend a TID to be a donor after the end of the TID's expenditure period?
A: Yes. The municipality can adopt an allocation amendment resolution after the donor TID's expenditure period ends. The municipality must adopt the amendment resolution before the donor or recipient TIDs reach their maximum life.

Q: What does project costs for "low-cost housing" mean for a mixed-use or industrial type recipient?
A:
Project plans for a mixed-use or industrial type TID must include costs to create, provide, or rehabilitate low-cost housing to become a recipient of increment funds from a donor TID.
State law does not define the term "low-cost housing." The municipality should consult its attorney to determine if the recipient TID's costs meet the requirement.
The municipality is responsible for providing an explanation of how the recipient TID's project plan meets the requirement in sec. 66.1105(6)(f)2.a. , Wis. Stats. The Wisconsin Department of Revenue (DOR) does not review or approve project costs. However, DOR confirms the recipient TID meets the requirements to receive allocated funds.

Q: Can the municipality create a Tax Incremental District (TID) that includes annexed parcels before approving the annexation?
A: No. The municipality annexing the property must approve the annexation ordinance before the municipality can adopt the TID creation resolution.

Q: What additional documents does a municipality have to provide to the Wisconsin Department of Revenue if a TID creation or territory amendment includes annexed parcels?
A:
When parcels annexed after January 1 of the TID creation or amendment year are included in the TID, the municipality must provide:
- Separate set of base value forms for the annexed parcels
- Town clerk and assessor must provide the necessary information
- List the town parcel numbers  include the new (city or village) parcel numbers, if available
- Copies of the annexation documents including the municipal ordinance approving the annexation

Q: Which parcel numbers should be shown (town or city/village) on the TID map? The town parcel numbers or the city/village parcel numbers?
A: When a TID includes parcels annexed after January 1 of the creation or amendment year, show the town parcel numbers. The parcel numbers on the map must match the value forms and the assessment roll.

Q: If annexed property is included in a TID and a court later reverses the annexation, how is the TID affected?
A: If a court order reverses the annexation, the municipality must complete a territory amendment to remove the affected property from the TID. A TID can only include property in the municipality that created the TID.

Q: If a town is annexed by a city before a TID created by the town under a cooperative agreement reaches its maximum life, can the city continue to collect the increments to pay for the town projects?
A: Yes. Under state law (sec. 66.1105(16)(c) , Wis. Stats.), when a town TID created under a cooperative agreement with a city (or village) is annexed by that city (or village), the city (or village) administers the TID as if it were created by that city (or village).

Q: Where can I find annexation ordinances for a specific municipality?
A: The Wisconsin Department of Administration (DOA) approves and publishes annexation ordinances statewide. To view the list, visit the DOA Municipal Data System-Ordinances .

Q: What audits and reports does a municipality with a Tax Incremental District (TID) need to complete?
A:
Under state law, a municipalitymust completethe following audits and reports:
- Audits Municipality must complete three Certified Public Accountant (CPA) audits during the TID's life. First audit Required within 12 months after the municipality reaches 30% of the TID's total expenditures Save a copy in the municipal TID records If a municipality adds additional project costs as part of a project plan amendment, another "first audit" is required when the expenditures again reach 30% Second audit Required within 12 months after the end of the expenditure period Save a copy in the municipal TID records Final audit Required within 12 months after the TID is terminated Save a copy in the municipal TID records E-file the TID Final Accounting Report ( Form PE-110 ) with DOR See Municipal TIF Termination for all documents and steps required when a TID terminates
- First audit Required within 12 months after the municipality reaches 30% of the TID's total expenditures Save a copy in the municipal TID records If a municipality adds additional project costs as part of a project plan amendment, another "first audit" is required when the expenditures again reach 30%
- Required within 12 months after the municipality reaches 30% of the TID's total expenditures
- Save a copy in the municipal TID records
- If a municipality adds additional project costs as part of a project plan amendment, another "first audit" is required when the expenditures again reach 30%
- Second audit Required within 12 months after the end of the expenditure period Save a copy in the municipal TID records
- Required within 12 months after the end of the expenditure period
- Save a copy in the municipal TID records
- Final audit Required within 12 months after the TID is terminated Save a copy in the municipal TID records E-file the TID Final Accounting Report ( Form PE-110 ) with DOR See Municipal TIF Termination for all documents and steps required when a TID terminates
- Required within 12 months after the TID is terminated
- Save a copy in the municipal TID records
- E-file the TID Final Accounting Report ( Form PE-110 ) with DOR
- See Municipal TIF Termination for all documents and steps required when a TID terminates
- TID Annual Report Municipalities with an active TID must e-file a TID Annual Report ( Form PE-300 ) with DOR for each TID. Important dates Due July 1  municipality must e-file this report with DOR every year, using the previous year's information By July 1 or when the report is available for review  municipality must hold a meeting with the Joint Review Board (representatives of the overlying taxing jurisdictions  municipality, county, school, technical college and a public member) to review the TID Annual Report Grace Period State law allows a 60-day grace period from the due date before the penalty applies After the grace period, the penalty is $100 per TID per day until the TID Annual Report is e-filed
- Important dates Due July 1  municipality must e-file this report with DOR every year, using the previous year's information By July 1 or when the report is available for review  municipality must hold a meeting with the Joint Review Board (representatives of the overlying taxing jurisdictions  municipality, county, school, technical college and a public member) to review the TID Annual Report
- Due July 1  municipality must e-file this report with DOR every year, using the previous year's information
- By July 1 or when the report is available for review  municipality must hold a meeting with the Joint Review Board (representatives of the overlying taxing jurisdictions  municipality, county, school, technical college and a public member) to review the TID Annual Report
- Grace Period State law allows a 60-day grace period from the due date before the penalty applies After the grace period, the penalty is $100 per TID per day until the TID Annual Report is e-filed
- State law allows a 60-day grace period from the due date before the penalty applies
- After the grace period, the penalty is $100 per TID per day until the TID Annual Report is e-filed

Q: Can the municipal audit take the place of the TID Annual Report?
A: No. A municipality must e-file a TID Annual Report ( Form PE-300 ) by July 1 with DOR.

Q: Does the first audit occur when the municipality reaches 30% of the capital expenditures or 30% of the total expenditures?
A: The first audit should be completed after the municipality paid 30% of the expected total TID costs, based on the current project plan. The total costs include any eligible TID costs (ex: fees, financing or professional services).

Q: If the municipality amends the project plan to add costs after reaching 30% of project expenditures and completed a first audit, does the municipality need to complete another first audit?
A: Yes. If the municipality approved an amendment to increase the project costs and has not paid 30% of the amended project costs, the municipality must repeat the audit when reaching 30% of the amended project costs.

Q: If the municipality finished a TID's final audit, but continued to incur additional project costs, is the municipality required to complete another final audit?
A: Yes. The final audit must cover all TID costs. A municipality must complete another final audit after all project costs are paid or it must arrange to cover future expenditures (ex: bond payments) from a source other than the TID fund.

Q: If a municipality terminates a TID before the end of the expenditure period when the second audit is required, can the municipality skip the second audit?
A: Yes. However, the final audit is required and needs to explain the timing and why there is no  second audit. As an example, the second audit was not required because the TID terminated early and never reached 12 months after the end of the expenditure period.

Q: What determines the last reporting year for the TID Annual Report (Form PE-300)?
A: The municipal termination resolution adoption date determines the last year a municipality must file the TID Annual Report. See the TID Termination Timeframes table for details.

Q: Our municipality terminated a TID before April 15 this year. Why is the Annual Report still required?
A: Each year, the municipality must file the TID Annual Report with the prior year's revenues and expenditures. When the municipality terminates the TID by April 15 of the current year, it was still active in the prior tax year, so the municipality must file the Annual Report.

Q: What determines the first reporting year for the TID Annual Report?
A: The municipal creation resolution adoption date determines the first year a municipality must file the TID Annual Report. See the TID Creation Timeframes table for details.

Q: When completing the TID Annual Report for the first time, how should a municipality account for expenses in the prior year when the Annual Report was not required?
A: The municipality should work with an accountant or auditor to determine whether to include the expenses on the first Annual Report or keep them separate. The municipality must document these expenses and include them in the TID Final Accounting Report at the end of the TID's life.

Q: How does the municipality determine the amount of "future costs" and "future revenue" on the TID Annual Report?
A:
The municipality can use a recent cash flow statement and/or the most recent approved project plan to estimate these amounts.
